business.start.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Paul Calvert) took the chair at 9.30 a.m. and read prayers.

talker.name: Abetz, Sen Eric
Senator ABETZ
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I rise on a brief point of order. I request that you investigate the Hansard tape from yesterday's question time. You will recall, Mr President, that I raised a point of order during question time asserting that Senator Chris Evans may have said something unparliamentary, in response to which Senator Evans rose to his feet and asserted that he had said certain words to you. The difficulty for Senator Evans is that the Hansard tape—and I have a copy of it in my office—clearly discloses that what he said to you is not what he said by way of interjection. It is my respectful submission that that is deserving of investigation and that, depending on your investigation, Senator Evans ought to come back into this place and apologise to the Senate for seeking to mislead you.

speech.para: I will not take the matter any further at this stage; suffice to say that we all say things in the heat of the moment and are requested to withdraw them from time to time—and that is fine. But to then try to cover that up and mislead the President by asserting that words were spoken other than those that were actually spoken is, I believe, a matter of moment. It is a serious matter and one that is deserving of investigation. I do not take the matter any further.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, on the point of order: Senator Abetz just made a number of assertions. He asserted them as matters of fact and matters of truth. He has asked for an inquiry to be conducted. He has made certain allegations.
—Are you taking a point of order?
—I am.
—Are you seeking leave to make a statement? You can't just get up and talk.
—Order!
—I am seeking that the allegations made be—
—Order! Senator Campbell, I am running this show, not you. He is speaking to the point of order. He is allowed to speak to the point of order.
—He has asked you to review something.
—He has not; he has asked to speak to the point of order. Senator Abetz took a point of order. Senator Bishop is speaking to that point of order, which is quite within order.

—Thank you, Chair. Senator Abetz is making assertions. He is asserting them as matters of fact. I request that those assertions be withdrawn pending review by yourself—if you choose to conduct a review. That is the point of order I am taking.
—Now you are taking a point of order. Make up your mind, you goose.
—Stay with the point of order, you fool.
—You're a goose.
—You're a fool.

—Order! You are both out of order. You are both using unparliamentary language and I would ask you to come to order. I had intended to review the tape. I did review the Hansard and what Senator Evans alleged that he said was not unparliamentary. If it is possible to review the tape and find out what the allegedly offensive words were, I will. Thank you, Senator Abetz.
—I raise a point of order. Senator Abetz has made imputations—
—Senator Bishop, I have already ruled on what I am going to do: I am going to review the tape.
—On a further point of order, I seek that the imputations made against Senator Evans be withdrawn at this stage until your review is concluded.
—Mr President, I am happy to withdraw pending your investigation. I look forward to Senator Evans's apology.

subdebate.1.para: Senator IAN CAMPBELL (Western Australia—Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (9.35 a.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That consideration of the business before the Senate on Wednesday, 12 May 2004 be interrupted at approximately 5 pm, but not so as to interrupt a senator speaking, to enable Senator Fifield to make his first speech without any question before the chair.

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.
Debate resumed from 1 March, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Postal Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 seeks to amend the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 and other acts of this parliament. These amendments seek to implement a variety of consumer and regulatory reforms to Australia Post and the postal services industry. Labor support some but not all of the measures contained in the bill. Broadly speaking, Labor support the aspects of the bill which enhance the ACCC's ability to ensure that Australia Post is not cross-subsidising its competitive services from its reserve core service in an uncompetitive manner. We will be opposing the provisions in the bill that deregulate document exchange and aggregation services. We will seek to protect these services within the ambit of Australia Post reserve services. These provisions represent a first small step towards the deregulation of Australia Post. Labor oppose these provisions absolutely. We will also oppose the provisions in the bill transferring the monitoring of Australia Post from the Auditor-General to the Australian Communications Authority. We do, however, support in principle the improvements to regional standards monitoring associated with this section. I will now consider the bill in more detail.

speech.para: The bill contains measures to enable the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, the ACCC, to determine whether Australia Post is cross-subsidising its competitive services from its core reserved service. These will allow the ACCC to ensure that Australia Post is not cross-subsidising its non-reserved services to the detriment of competitors such as newsagents. The measures will allow the ACCC to keep detailed accounting and auditing information about Australia Post's reserved services. The bill will also allow the ACCC to inquire into disputes regarding the rate reduction Australia Post allows its bulk mail customers.

Australia Post should not be able to use the benefits derived from its reserved services to unfairly undermine competition in other, non-reserved areas. This is why Labor supports the greater scrutiny of Australia Post by the ACCC. However, Labor supports absolutely the continuation of Australia Post's reserved service. Around 85 per cent of Australia Post's activities are now fully contestable. It is important that in these areas the playing field between Australia Post and its private sector competitors be even and fair.

Labor welcome most of these initiatives and are happy to support them. However, we have some concerns that the new ACCC role is to be funded by a levy on Australia Post. The estimated cost to Australia Post is up to $3.5 million per year. Furthermore, the people who will benefit from the new ACCC role are likely to be Australia Post's competitors. This money will ultimately come out of Australia Post's profits and its annual dividend to the government. Telstra, with its $3-plus billion profits, did not have similar levies placed on it in the same circumstances. Despite our concerns, and in the absence of an alternative funding model, Labor will support for now the government's new funding model for the ACCC's Australia Post role. However, we will be monitoring this funding arrangement very carefully.

Some of our key concerns about the bill lie with schedule 1 amendment items 11 through to 14. These amendments legitimise certain practices of document exchange and aggregation services. They represent the first step towards the deregulation of Australia Post's core reserved articles. Labor oppose these amendments and will be moving to strike out this section of the bill. It is clear that the Howard government's long-term policy ambition is to deregulate and eventually privatise Australia Post. Under this bill the carriage of letters from an aggregation services customer to an aggregator will be excised from Australia Post's reserved services. Labor reject these provisions. The bill also provides that the carriage of letters between a document exchange customer and a document exchange centre will be exempted from Australia Post's reserved services coverage. Again, Labor reject this weakening of Australia Post's reserved service. The provisions amount to a further deregulation of Australia Post's services.

Australia Post cannot be expected to adequately undertake its strict community service obligations if its reserved mail services are gradually opened up to further competition. Australia Post's community service obligation depends on the retention of its reserved service area. This provides an accessible standard letter service to all Australians at a uniform cost. History has vindicated the former Labor government's model for Australia Post's reserved services. Australia Post has achieved outstanding financial and service performance in recent years under both Labor and coalition governments. Australia Post's current regulatory settings are good for the economy and useful for general mail users. Australia Post's outstanding performance levels have been achieved because its core responsibility, the standard letter, is still reserved.

Australia has a relatively small population distributed very unevenly across an enormous landmass. This means that it is essential that we have some mechanism for cross-subsidisation of our basic postal services to ensure that all Australians throughout our society can communicate adequately by post. In 2000 the government tried to enact the Postal Services Legislation Amendment Bill, which also pursued its deregulatory agenda. Fortunately the bill was withdrawn due to lack of support in parliament, including on the government's own side. But the government's deregulatory agenda remains apparent, as demonstrated in the bill before us today.

The other aspect of the bill which Labor opposes is the proposed new Australia Post monitoring role for the Australian Communications Authority. This is the proposed new part 4A, division 1 of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989. At present the Auditor-General monitors Australia Post's service standards. The government is proposing in this bill to transfer this function to the Australian Communications Authority. Labor prefers that the current role of the Auditor-General remain in place. The Auditor-General, as we all know, is completely independent of the communications minister, but the ACA is not sufficiently independent of the government to monitor Australia Post's standards and costs.

In the telecommunications area, the ACA was exposed last year for reporting statistics which portrayed Telstra's annual network fault levels in an extremely favourable and misleading light. Just in the last few months a leaked internal Telstra document further exposed the weaknesses in the ACA's telecommunications monitoring role. This leaked Telstra document showed that Telstra's soaring fault levels were due to network neglect. In Labor's view, the Auditor-General represents a much more independent and robust institution for monitoring Australia Post's performance.

The government is now in the process of reviewing future arrangements for its two communications regulators, the ABA and the ACA. The minister referred to this possible merger in a speech earlier this year. It is therefore premature to grant either of these agencies significant new powers before that review is concluded. At the committee stage we will oppose the entirety of the proposed new part 4A, division 1 of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989. We will also be opposing the repeal of division 1A of part 3 of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989, contained in item 10 of this bill, which effectively repeals the Auditor-General's postal monitoring role. However, Labor do support the proposed new section—

talk.start.para: —I rise on a point of order. Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Bishop seems to be in breach of standing order 187. He is reading word for word from a speech off a lectern and not making any attempt to deliver a speech. He is just reading word for word from a prepared text, which is clearly in breach of the standing orders. I would like you to draw that to his attention.
(Senator Brandis)—I direct Senator Bishop's attention to standing order 187.

—This provides a mechanism to enable the measurement of Australia Post's service delivery arrangements. This amendment is designed to improve the assessment of whether delivery services should be provided to particular communities. Under current processes it is difficult for communities to convince Australia Post to institute delivery services to particular areas.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Perhaps Senator Bishop is not aware of standing order 187. It specifically says:

quote.para: A senator shall not read a speech.

interjection.para: Senator Bishop is reading a speech, which is in direct breach of the standing orders. He is not referring to copious notes; he is reading word for word from a prepared text, which is clearly in breach of standing orders.

talk.start.para: —Minister, assuming Senator Bishop was not aware of standing order 187, which I very much doubt, the effect of it was plainly conveyed by your first point of order. I must confess that I was not observing Senator Bishop speaking when you made your first point of order. In the time between your first and your second points of order I did look at him. I do not think that he is trespassing beyond the understanding of standing order 187 in relation to copious notes.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: perhaps when Senator Bishop has concluded his reading of his text he will be kind enough to assist Hansard by tabling it. I think that that is often his practice. Perhaps you could compare his prepared text with the Hansard record and see if in fact he has read it word for word. That would be a good test for it.
—Minister, I do not think that that is a point of order.
—That standing order is now defunct, is it?
—No. I do not think you are taking a point of order; you are suggesting a course of action, but I do not think you are taking a point of order.

—I was just making a comment that the government had instituted a review of its two communications agencies—the ABA and the ACA. The comments I made were in the context of the speech having been prepared some time ago. I am now advised that the government last evening announced a merger of the ABA and the ACA.
—That's the trouble with reading a prepared text.
—Why don't you keep your mouth shut and listen to the speech!
—Senator Bishop, order! Do not address another senator like that. Senator Ian Campbell, you remain silent, too.

—Under current processes it is difficult for communities to convince Australia Post to institute delivery services to particular areas. While Labor support these provisions in principle, we will propose a different way of achieving the same outcome. We will do this by moving an amendment for a new section 28C(3) of the Australian Postal Corporation Act, enhancing the Auditor-General's delivery arrangements role. This will enhance the Auditor-General's existing role and achieve the same outcome through a different agency. It will also ensure that communities can gain decent access to Australia Post services where appropriate. The government also proposes a new section 50E to allow the minister to direct the ACA to monitor and report to the minister on specified matters relating to Australia Post's supply of postal services. Again, Labor have no problems with this new provision. We will move that the same function outlined in section 50E be entrusted to the Auditor-General, not to the ACA.

speech.para: One reform that would have benefited consumers which is not in the bill and should be is the establishment of a postal industry ombudsman. The government promised such an ombudsman prior to the last election to improve consumer outcomes in the postal sector. Such an ombudsman would apply to all postal service operators, not just Australia Post. More than two years into the government's term and approaching the end of that term, the government has not yet legislated for this significant reform. Until the government implements its postal ombudsman proposal, that proposal can only be regarded as a broken promise. Finally, there are some minor provisions in this bill—items 23 and 24—which are technical amendments to update the Australian Postal Corporation Act. Labor supports these latter amendments. I will speak further to the amendments in committee.

talk.start.para: —The Postal Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 makes amendments to the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 to do a number of things. It shifts responsibility from the Auditor-General and provides the Australian Communications Authority with responsibility for the oversight of, and reporting on, Australia Post's supply of postal services. It requires the ACCC to make record-keeping rules for Australia Post and to inquire into disputes in relation to the terms and conditions of Australia Post's bulk interconnection services. It makes changes to Australia Post's reserved services in relation to document exchange and aggregation. The bill is a very distant relative of the Postal Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2000, which proposed more extensive deregulation of the postal service industry and which the Democrats emphatically opposed. While this bill is much less wide reaching and less ideologically driven than the previous bill, we will not be supporting all of the provisions in this bill either.

speech.para: In one of its first key areas, the bill aims to shift to the Australian Communications Authority responsibility for the monitoring of, and reporting on, the supply of postal services. The authority would be required to measure Australia Post's performance against prescribed performance standards, a job currently undertaken by the Auditor-General. It would be required to calculate the cost to Australia Post of carrying out community service obligations which are currently performed by Post, based on a model developed by the government. It would be required to monitor and report to the minister on specific matters relating to Australia Post's supply of postal services—an activity not currently performed by anybody at all.

The government has argued that, as Australia Post retains a monopoly over the delivery of reserved letters and there is no impetus of competition to drive improvements in the delivery of services, the involvement of the authority is therefore needed to drive improvements in the delivery of the services provided by Australia Post. But the government has never demonstrated that any tangible benefits would flow to the community from such deregulation. It has at best asserted that increased competition will improve the postal services industry, but it has not actually proven that that will occur. The Democrats are very cynical about the claims of competition policy. We have had too much experience with deregulation and competition policy having adverse effects to believe assertions anymore.

The Democrats do not share the government's concerns regarding the need for competition in postal services. Australia Post is already one of the most efficient postal services in the world. It provides an excellent level of service at a uniform rate to all Australians, regardless of where they live, across this country. Its level of customer satisfaction is among the highest of any Australian company. It is in an enviable position in comparison with the private sector. In areas with dubious telephone reception, banks that have closed and state government services that are being withdrawn, Australia Post services still operate.

The government has also argued that the involvement of the authority is necessary to establish a consumer complaints mechanism. But, again, the government has failed to provide any data to demonstrate that need. There already exist two separate consumer complaints mechanisms: one through the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the other through Australia Post itself. The Ombudsman's dispute mechanism assists consumers to settle their differences with suppliers of goods and services informally and quickly and operates as such for a further 14 government departments, including the tax office. In its most recent annual report, the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman talked about Australia Post. It stated:

quote.para: The total number of complaints received this year was 1,082, compared to 1,060 in 2000-01 and the 2001-02 total of 896 ...

To put some perspective to these figures, every day of the year, Australia Post moves in excess of 18 million articles (this figure reaches 50 million in the days prior to Christmas). The proportion of complaints received by the Ombudsman is therefore a small percentage of the total number of transactions undertaken by Australia Post.

Much of the reason for this can be attributed to the generally high level of service that Australia Post provides to its customers and its own effective handling of complaints by its Customer Contact Centres in each State.

speech.para: In addition to the Ombudsman, complaints can be made to Australia Post itself through its customer service centres within each state, either via a 131 telephone number or via the Internet. Of the estimated four million customer contacts a year, Australia Post estimates that less than five per cent are customer complaints, the majority of which are resolved in a timely manner. All complaints are lodged on a database and can be easily accessed for crosschecking and follow-up. Indeed, Australia Post's complaints mechanism has been praised by the Ombudsman. On page 139 of the Commonwealth Ombudsman's 2001-02 annual report, the Ombudsman refers to the outcomes of a review by the office of the operations of Australia Post customer care centres. The report says:

quote.para: ... my office ... confirmed a higher degree of commitment and support to effective complaint handling by management of Australia Post.

speech.para: Not only does the Ombudsman's office believe that the number of complaints is small but it also believes that Australia Post has an effective complaints handling procedure. The Democrats, as a result, can see no particular reason to argue for a multimillion dollar extra impost for the Communications Authority to handle that complaints mechanism for Australia Post. It is simply not needed.

The government also argues that the ACA is a more appropriate body than the Auditor-General to monitor postal services, as the ACA is the regulator of telecommunications and radio communications. However, the Democrats share the concern expressed at various times by the opposition that the efficiency and the effectiveness of the ACA's role in monitoring telecommunications are actually open for doubt. We would like to see improvements to how the ACA performs that role before we would support any consideration of the ACA's role being expanded, whether it be into postal or broadcasting roles. We certainly believe that the Auditor-General performs a very good monitoring role at present at a much lower cost than what it would cost the ACA to do it, as proposed by this bill.

The Democrats are very concerned by the whole issue of the cost of this ACA monitoring role. The inquiry into this bill heard that the initial cost could be around $2 million and ongoing costs would be around $2.5 million a year, levied from Australia Post on an ongoing basis. We are concerned that this cost would affect Australia Post's profit and, ultimately, the level of return to shareholders in the form of income tax or dividends.

There are two questions that need to be asked as a result of all this: is the problem as articulated by the government significant enough that the costs are justified and will the potential benefits outweigh those costs? In our view, the answer to both these questions is a clear and emphatic no. The Democrats will not be supporting the government provisions relating to the Australian Communications Authority's role and will support Labor's amendments to expand the proposed monitoring and reporting activities as part of the Auditor-General's role.

The second area of amendments to this bill relates to the expanding role for the ACCC. Currently, the postal act provides for the ACCC to inquire into disputes about the rate of reduction offered by Australia Post to its bulk mail customers. The bill aims to broaden the scope of the ACCC's power to inquire. The Bills Digest notes that, since the introduction of these measures in 1994, the ACCC has been notified of no such disputes—none whatsoever in 10 years. We certainly question the necessity to expand these powers further, given that they have not been used. However, I do concede that this provision is broadly consistent with other legislation under which the ACCC operates and therefore we will not be opposing the amendment, although we are not convinced that it is absolutely necessary either.

The bill also provides for the ACCC to make record-keeping rules for Australia Post. The reason for this amendment is, as I understand it, because concerns have been raised in the past that Australia Post competes unfairly by cross-subsidising its competitive services with revenue from its reserved services. The National Competition Council examined this issue in 1998 and found no evidence to support these claims. But the council did recommend that there be a requirement for detailed independent auditing and accounting information to provide transparency of this financial relationship to avoid any further concern being raised. It is estimated that this particular role will cost the ACCC about $600,000 a year. Again, we have concerns about the cost benefit trade-off, especially given that to date no evidence has been found that cross-subsidising is occurring between Australia Post reserved and competitive services. Australia Post has assured us that the cost and accounting requirements of this measure will not affect postal licensees and that they are reasonably comfortable with what is being proposed, so from that point of view we will not be opposing these amendments either.

The final area of this bill relates to changes to Australia Post reserved services in relation to document exchange and aggregation services. The Democrats believe that the amendments will not lead to a further erosion of reserved services but merely permit an activity within a broad service provided by mail aggregation and document exchange service providers which Australia Post currently does not participate in, namely, the picking up and delivering of reserved mail from the service provider to the customer. The core service provided by mail aggregation and document exchange providers does not change. It seems to me rather silly that a mail aggregation service provider can legally accept from a customer, aggregate and transfer reserved mail to Australia Post but cannot pick it up from the customer. I do not see how allowing mail aggregation service providers to pick up the bulk mail will change in any way their core business or take business away from Australia Post. Surely, Australia Post should not be expected to pick up the bulk mail from a customer and drop it off to a mail aggregation service provider.

Similarly, with document exchange provision, document exchange service providers can legally transfer reserved mail and documents between document exchange service providers, can accept certain reserved mail and documents from customers and can pick up documents but cannot pick up the reserved mail from customers. Again, this seems an anomaly rather than a major expansion of services. I am a little surprised that Labor is opposing these amendments, given that it was Labor in 1984 that initially excluded these document exchange services from Australia Post's reserved services. I understand that Labor's changes from 1994 have not negatively impacted on Australia Post's performance. Indeed, Australia Post made a record profit in the three years after the changes.

In the Senate inquiry into this bill, the Communications, Electrical and Plumbing Union raised concerns that the changes in the profitable sections of the postal market may lead to major growth in the activities of alternative providers competing against Australia Post and would undermine the financial foundation of the reserved service operation. Australia Post has expressed, both publicly and privately, that it is not concerned with this particular provision and that the proposed changes will not have a negative effect on its bottom line. In correspondence with my office, Australia Post has stated:

quote.para: Aggregation is of benefit to Australia Post, because it provides Post with more mail that can be processed more efficiently and for significantly less cost. The revenue reduction is more than outweighed by the associated cost savings. Australia Post has confirmed that the aggregation amendment in the Postal Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 will not have any negative impact on its bottom line profit.

speech.para: Australia Post believes that the inclusion of safeguards in this bill with respect to document exchange services will prevent the expansion of these services into the Australia Post core market. I note that a number of safeguards have been included in the bill as it stands. But we are proposing to pick up the further recommendation from the Senate inquiry to include a mechanism to tighten up the penalties for breaches of reserved services. Currently, section 31 of the Australian Postal Corporation Act provides:

quote.para: Where a person has engaged, or is proposing to engage, in conduct that involves ... an infringement of Australia Post's ... reserved services, Australia Post may apply to the Federal Court for relief.

speech.para: It further provides:

quote.para: The relief that may be granted includes an injunction and, at the option of Australia Post, either damages or an account of profits.

speech.para: However, we believe that a penalty provision will act as a further deterrent and we will be moving such an amendment, based on a similar provision that exists in the Telecommunications Act. I reserve my further comments for the committee stage.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —I thank senators for their contributions. It is true that Australia Post holds a unique position in the Australian landscape. All Australians to some extent, and many to a great extent, use the services of Australia Post. Because of its importance to the Australian community, it is desirable to do whatever is possible to make sure that businesses and residential consumers can be confident about the ongoing quality of Australia Post's services.

speech.para: The Postal Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 is a package of postal reforms designed to significantly improve regulatory and consumer aspects of the current postal legislative regime. The legislation, if supported by the Senate, will deliver certainty to small business and benefits to Australian consumers. For consumers it will, for the first time, provide a truly independent consumer focused oversight of Australia Post's performance. For small business participating in the postal market it will clarify the arrangements and provide operating certainty.

For example, the legislation gives the Australian Communications Authority, the ACA, the power to monitor and report on Australia Post's supply of postal services. These amendments will safeguard the interests of the users of the postal system and ensure that the highest quality of service is being provided to the public. The ACA will also be responsible for calculating the cost to Australia Post of fulfilling its community service obligations. The fact that the government has announced the merger of the ABA and the ACA does not change the government's approach. The legislation will also extend the powers of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to enable it to inquire into disputes about any of the terms and conditions of a bulk mail service. This will be of significant benefit to businesses that are major mail users.

For some time now there have been concerns among some small business operators such as newsagents and gift shops that Australia Post is taking advantage of its reserved service mail business to compete with these businesses. To address these concerns, the bill will allow the ACCC to require Australia Post to keep records about the financial relationship between different parts of its business and to publish reports. This, I believe, will ensure greater transparency of Australia Post's operations and therefore allow the investigation of any possible cross-subsidisation between retail operations and the reserved services business. Other provisions in the bill will provide certainty to small businesses who use document exchanges or who aggregate their mail in order to gain access to Australia Post bulk mail discounts. Contrary to the claims of the opposition, these are not at all related to deregulation. They simply clarify the existing operations of the postal services market. Finally, I draw to the attention of the Senate that the legislation extends the government's postal regulation powers to prescribe the procedures that Australia Post must follow in polling communities to determine whether or not they require the property services. This will be of particular benefit to people living in remote areas of Australia.

I note that both the opposition and the Democrats are proposing to move amendments to the bill. The government also propose to move amendments to the bill. These government amendments will clarify and simplify the cost recovery mechanism to fund the new postal roles of the ACA and the ACCC. The amendments are technical in nature and put in place appropriate payment processes. They do not change the government's objectives or intentions or the operation of the bill. The government will not support opposition amendments to the legislation since they would, if accepted, undermine the government's intended reforms. The government will not support the Democrat amendments as we consider, Senator Cherry, that they are unnecessary. We have carefully weighed up these matters and have come to those conclusions.

The government considers all the reforms contained in the bill to be in the public interest. The package of measures contained in this bill represents a serious attempt to improve the overall operation and regulatory scrutiny of the postal services market for the benefit of all. The measures will improve the quality of service regulation and hence, we believe, consumer confidence in Australia Post. They provide clarity and certainty to small business participants in postal services, they clarify the operation of the market for users of bulk mail services and they address concerns about possible unfair cross-subsidisation by Australia Post. Importantly, Australia Post itself supports these measures. The government considers that it is important for the bill to be passed as soon as possible, as delaying the potential benefits to consumers and businesses is unjustifiable. I look forward to the cooperation of the Senate.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move opposition amendments (1) and (2) on the second revised sheet 4149:

quote.para: (1) Clause 4, page 2 (line 4) to page 3 (line 2), omit subclauses (1) to (5).
(2) Clause 4, page 3 (lines 8 to 14), omit subclause (7).

speech.para: We also oppose division 1 in item 21 and items 1 to 6, 8 to 10 and 19 and 20 in the following terms:

quote.para: (3) Schedule 1, items 1 to 5, page 4 (lines 4 to 27), TO BE OPPOSED.
(4) Schedule 1, item 6, page 4 (line 29) to page 5 (line 2), TO BE OPPOSED.
(5) Schedule 1, items 8 to 10, page 5 (lines 7 to 16), TO BE OPPOSED.
(10) Schedule 1, items 19 and 20, page 7 (lines 26 to 30), TO BE OPPOSED.
(11) Schedule 1, item 21, page 8 (line 2) to page 11 (line 14), Division 1, TO BE OPPOSED.

speech.para: These amendments and opposed schedules seek to reject the bill's provisions transferring the Australia Post monitoring role from the Auditor-General to the ACA. Labor, as I foreshadowed in the second reading debate, rejects this part of the bill. Labor's opposed schedule (11) rejecting division 1 of item 21 is the key opposed schedule rejecting the new ACA role, and the remaining opposed schedules—(3), (4),(5) and (10)—are consequential on the success of the prime opposed schedule getting up.

Labor amendments (1) and (2) omit subclauses 1 to 5 and 7 of clause 4 of the bill under discussion. These are savings provisions relating to this bill's attempts to transfer the Australia Post monitoring role from the Auditor-General to the ACA. Labor's opposed schedule (3) removes items 1 to 5 of schedule 1 of this bill. These items, as is clear, seek to amend the Australian Communications Authority Act 1997 for the purposes of facilitating the ACA's new postal role, which Labor rejects.

Labor's opposed schedules (4) and (5) remove items 6, 8, 9 and 10 of schedule 1 of the bill. These items are part of the amendments to the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 which facilitate the new postal monitoring role for the Australian Communications Authority. Item 10 of the bill is of note, we believe, because it is the clause that effectively repeals the Auditor-General's postal monitoring role. Labor's opposed schedule (10) removes items 19 and 20 of schedule 1. These items also amend the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 to help facilitate the new postal monitoring role for the Australian Communications Authority. Labor's opposed schedule (11) omits division 1 of item 21 of this bill. This is the substantive division outlining in detail the ACA's new role, which is the central feature of our objection and the reasons for putting forward these amendments and opposed schedules.

In the bill many of the clauses relating to the Auditor-General's existing postal monitoring roles are simply transferred without change in any way to the Australian Communications Authority. The same functions, the same powers and the same processes in the old act are proposed to be transferred into the new bill. The central difference is that the monitoring authority will be the ACA and not the Auditor-General. Several new provisions are included relating to delivery arrangements, ministerial discretion and additional reports, so there are some changes there. However, Labor reject division 1 of item 21 of the bill because we do not believe in the new postal monitoring role for the ACA and prefer that it remain with the Auditor-General.

In summary, our position is that at present the Auditor-General adequately monitors Australia Post service standards. The government is proposing in this bill to transfer this function to the ACA. Labor prefer that this current role for the Auditor-General remain in place. We believe that the Auditor-General is completely independent of the communications minister and we are not so satisfied, based upon the performance of the ACA in more recent years, that it can be confidently asserted that the ACA is similarly robust, independent and free from ministerial discretion in the way it carries out its duties, its performance and its critical role. We believe that the Auditor-General has monitored Australia Post effectively and competently. We do not believe the ACA is sufficiently independent of government to monitor Australia Post service standards and costs.

In the telecommunications area the ACA was exposed last year with reported statistics which portrayed Telstra's annual network fault levels in an extremely favourable light. In the last few weeks alone it has been the subject of debate in this place and elsewhere with regard to leaked Telstra documents which show that Telstra's soaring fault levels are due predominantly to network neglect and a failure to have sufficient capital investment, and not bad weather, as was alleged by Telstra, the government and the ACA in a rather protracted process. In Labor's view, the Auditor-General is a much more independent and robust institution for monitoring Australia Post's performance.

A further reason for not giving the ACA these new monitoring powers is that the government has announced the merger of the two communications regulators, the Australian Broadcasting Authority and the Australian Communications Authority, and we wish to observe that process before additional powers or transference of powers is effectively guaranteed. Labor therefore oppose all the provisions in the Postal Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 which transfer the Australia Post monitoring role from the Auditor-General to the ACA.

In summary, Labor believe that the Auditor-General does a competent and effective job at the moment in this area of his work and that the ACA's role as being properly independent of government and not open to political pressure is problematic—and I refer to recent instances where it has been under review. We say that the government has announced the merger of the ABA and the ACA, and Labor believe it is preferable to await the outcome of that merger before giving a new agency any extra roles, particularly with respect to Australia Post. We believe that the onus is on the government to demonstrate the need for change to the status quo. We are not satisfied that the government has brought sufficient or, indeed, any evidence to warrant ACA involvement in an area of activity which has generally been the subject of satisfactory regulatory oversight to date. In any event, we are not satisfied that the Auditor-General is not discharging its statutory functions adequately and, even if that were so, we do not believe that it is appropriate at this stage to have those roles transferred to the ACA.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will be supporting the opposition on this occasion in respect of the role of the ACA. As I outlined in my speech in the second reading debate, the Democrats do not believe that these provisions add significantly to the function of oversight of Australia Post and its services. Furthermore, the cost that would be incurred for these oversight provisions does not actually outweigh the benefits that they would provide. It is noteworthy that the Auditor-General has done this role, and quite effectively, over some considerable time. There have been no cases put up by the government to show that the Auditor-General is not doing that role effectively. From our point of view, we simply cannot see any merit in spending this money to have this oversight function done. No evidence has been presented to date to show that Australia Post itself needs an oversight and better accountability. Indeed, all the evidence suggests that, whether it be complaints from customers or the cost of services delivered or compliance with law, Australia Post is an exemplary government enterprise, and from that point of view these provisions are not needed.

speech.para: I would also like to note that we are actually saving the government some money by doing this for them. The cost of this oversight function is around $2½ million a year. After the enormous pork barrel that was rolled out last night, I think the government need every cent we can find for them. It is worth noting that the run-downs of the budget surpluses over the next four years are the equivalent of the complete cost of the selling of Telstra. It is worth noting at this stage that the government need every $2 million they can find if they are actually going to do anything in terms of preventing interest rates going up through a massive fiscal incentive. Whilst $2½ million might not sound like much, given that it is coming straight out of the Australia Post dividend and straight out of Australia Post services, I think it is quite beneficial that the Senate say to the government, `We have found a way for you not to spend money that would be spent unnecessarily and that would fail a cost-benefit analysis.' So, from that point of view, the Democrats are supportive of the opposition's view that the role currently undertaken by the Auditor-General should continue, with enhanced powers—which we will be talking about later on—and that the ACA should not be brought into this particular process.

I also note that the government announced last night that it will be merging the role of the ACA and the ABA. That is something which, again, the government needs to debate properly before we consider what extended role beyond that the ACA will take on. The notion of a regulator trying to carry out all the current powers of the ACA—which, in my view, it is not undertaking effectively anyway—and then taking on the roles of Professor Flint over at the ABA and getting new roles when at its core is a regulator which, as I said, is not doing its job properly, is something which we have to think about very carefully as a Senate and as a parliament. I think that should be done when the government brings forward its merger proposal for the ABA and the ACA, and we will see what we can make of it then. For those various reasons, the Democrats will be supporting the opposition on this occasion. These are unnecessary provisions. It is an unnecessary $2½ million impost on Australia Post. I certainly think that, from a fiscal point of view, the government should be doing everything it can to save money after its largesse last night.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —I think I have now heard just about everything in the Senate: the Democrats getting up and purporting to lecture the government about saving money! Senator Cherry, you should frame your comments. I think they were done with tongue in cheek, because the Democrats have never been the slightest bit interested in saving the government money. From day one of my being here, the Democrats' policy under various leaders—in fact, quite a few leaders—has been to spend, spend and spend again. So to see you stand up and attempt to lecture the government on fiscal prudence is, I would have to say, a unique experience in this chamber, never to be repeated. On Senator Bishop's comments, I must say that you know when the Labor Party are on weak ground. If they do not like a report, what do they always do? Attack the messenger.

speech.para: We had aspersions cast on the independence of the ACA. What was the substantive proof for this outrageous comment? The Labor Party did not like their report. Under Mr Latham, the Labor Party has spent a lot of time going around lecturing people about proper behaviour and proprieties and relations with public servants and independent bodies. The ACA board is staffed by distinguished people and you have just cast aspersions on them, quite carelessly, that somehow they are succumbing to pressures from Mr Daryl Williams and others. It is quite outrageous and should not be accepted.

As I pointed out, the government will not be accepting the amendments that have been moved by Senator Bishop. The proposals contained in the bill give the ACA an oversight role in relation to Australia Post by requiring the ACA to monitor and report on Australia Post's performance and supply of postal services. The opposition's proposal is that the monitoring role proposed for the ACA be given instead to the Auditor-General, an agency whose principal function is that of auditing. That proposal is, I would have thought, clearly weaker in terms of transparency and consumer protection than the government's proposal itself.

The ACA's new postal functions will benefit consumers. Senator Cherry was talking about costs. Senator Cherry, what about costs to consumers? Again, you show one of the famous blind spots of the Australian Democrats. What is good for consumers here? I think the government's proposal is clearly one which is of benefit to consumers. The ACA's new postal functions will be able to target specific matters for monitoring if there is general public concern about a particular matter relating to Australia Post's supply of postal services. At the moment I think it is true to say there is little, if any, independent oversight of Australia Post's postal functions other than an audit against performance standards. Under the government's proposed legislation there is the opportunity for the ACA to examine systemic failures on a geographical basis.

Other issues which the ACA could examine which are currently not done by the Auditor-General include geographic disaggregation of issues such as ongoing consumer complaints and late deliveries and/or service performance in the bush in comparison with metropolitan areas. The assessment of Australia Post's performance is, we believe, clearly more appropriately carried out by the ACA, which performs a similar role in relation to the telecommunications industry. The ACA, in the government's view, is an independent regulator—I stress `independent', Senator Bishop—with the requisite expertise to monitor and report on Australia Post's performance in the supply of postal services.

talk.start.para: (Senator Brandis)—The question is that division 1 of item 21 and items 1 to 6, 8 to 10, 19 and 20 of the bill stand as printed.
—The question now is that opposition amendments (1) and (2) be agreed to.
—The opposition opposes items 11 to 14 in schedule 1 in the following terms:

quote.para: (6) Schedule 1, items 11 to 14 , page 5 (line 17) to page 6 (line 34), TO BE OPPOSED.

speech.para: The opposition opposes the provisions in the bill which will deregulate certain aspects of aggregation and document exchange services amendments. Items 11 to 14 in schedule 1 of the bill seek to remove two services currently reserved to Australia Post: firstly, the carriage of letters from a customer of an aggregation service to the aggregator before lodgment with Australia Post under its bulk interconnection service and, secondly, the carriage of letters between the customers of a document exchange service and the document exchange.

We believe this effectively erodes Australia Post's existing level of reserved services by providing more exceptions to these services. The government has said that these provisions legitimise existing business practices—we understand that to be its position. What we say they would really do is legitimise practices currently being conducted which have no authority and which are in fact illegal. Australia Post's reserved services enable Australia Post to perform its community service obligation, as we all understand. This does truly enable Australia Post to provide all Australians with an accessible standard letter service at a uniform price. Chipping away at Australia Post's reserved service undermines Australia Post's ability to provide its community service obligation, which it is required to provide under the statute which creates the organisation. It is, we believe, a continuation of the government's attempts to deregulate and ultimately privatise Australia Post's services.

Australia Post's performance levels have been outstanding in recent times and have been achieved because they are its core responsibility, a standard letter being reserved as a monopoly to Australia Post. In no way do the Labor Party depart from their approval of that particular practice. For the last number of years, Labor have consistently opposed the further deregulation of Australia Post and the removal of services that it has under statutory monopolies. We believe it is more appropriate that Australia Post remains in full public ownership, delivering high-quality postal services to Australians across this land. If there are deficiencies in the carrying out of those services or in the carrying out of new services, we believe it is appropriate that Australia Post engages in improving its internal performances so that it can continue to deliver those services to all Australians. So we oppose these particular provisions that are currently before the committee. We support Australia Post as an integral part of Australia's social and economic fabric. Labor are not going to stand by and allow the Howard government to slowly erode, by chipping away, Australia Post's critical national functions, which it has been carrying out properly, effectively, efficiently and at a continuing low cost for many years.

We understand the Democrats may not be supporting the change proposed by the opposition which is opposing deregulation of Australia Post's reserved service, or certain aspects of that. We believe this position of the Democrats is regrettable. The government's first attempts to deregulate and ultimately privatise Australia Post will be given a hand by the Australian Democrats if they oppose the proposed change currently before the committee.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will be supporting the government amendments on this particular occasion. I think it is worth putting a few things on the record about the aggregation and document exchange services. This affects roughly one per cent of Australia Post's potential business, so we are talking about a very small part of Australia Post's business. Indeed, in coming to our view we took into careful account the views that were raised by the Post Office Agents Association and the CEPU in their submissions to the committee. The Post Office Agents Association were certainly concerned that they may lose business, and the CEPU thought it was rather odd that these provisions were about legalising activities which are currently illegal but in many cases are already being undertaken by document exchange services in collecting and delivering mail for their customers.

speech.para: At the end of the day, we really do not believe that these proposed provisions are the thin edge of the wedge, as Senator Bishop suggests, but rather that they are a fairly logical extension of what was already excluded from the reserved powers back in 1994. Rather than actually undermining Australia Post, we think they simply clarify what is currently allowed as an exclusion from the reserved powers, in terms of document exchange and aggregation. For the benefit of Senator Bishop, I would like to reiterate what I said in my opening comments regarding correspondence I received from Australia Post that said:

quote.para: Aggregation is of benefit to Australia Post, because it provides Post with more mail that can be processed more efficiently and for significantly less cost. The revenue reduction is more than outweighed by the associated cost savings.

speech.para: I think that is very important. I think the provisions we are talking about here are for the benefit of customers of document exchange and aggregation services—and I am sure Senator Kemp will be pleased to hear that I am talking about benefits for customers—but they are also about ensuring that we have a proper definition of what is the clear legal extent of document exchange and aggregation services.

The Democrats have also picked up the concern that the Post Office Agents Association raised about ensuring that, when we do set these clear standards in law, they are properly enforced by government and by Australia Post. That is why we will be moving later as an amendment something that was suggested in the committee evidence, and that is a provision to allow for further legal enforcement of these provisions by adopting a provision out of the Telecommunications Act. In relation to supporting the government's amendments at this stage, what should be remembered is that this is part of a broader package that we are proposing, which is to enforce more clearly these provisions through the penalty provisions in the amendment I will be moving later.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to commend the comments from Senator Cherry. Your form has improved rapidly this morning. You started off rather poorly with your first contribution, but you have been able to substantially recover ground with your second contribution. We commend the Australian Democrats for the approach that they are taking in relation to the change proposed by the opposition.

speech.para: You always know the Labor Party is on very weak ground when it starts to raise these real furphies. The truth is that the CEPU called Senator Bishop and said: `We're getting nervous again. We don't want any change; we're opposed to change'—as unions often are. So the Labor Party—as it always does; it has to when it gets a phone call from the union movement saying that it has to take particular action—has to do it. That is basically correct.

talk.start.para: —Senator Bishop, for your information and again to put on record, the government has on many occasions stated its commitment to maintaining Australia Post in full public ownership. Suggestions that the DX and aggregation provisions of the bill are intended as a precursor to further deregulation of postal services are absurd. This is the `thin edge of the wedge' which you constantly fall back on. I listened carefully to the arguments that you put forward—as I always do; I am a courteous senator and I always like to listen to contrary arguments that are put forward—but I have to say that your comments were basically absurd. We know why you made them: because the union movement, the CEPU, got on to you and gave you your instructions so, like all good Labor senators, you marched into this chamber and ran the CEPU line.

speech.para: Document exchange services provide important mail collection and delivery services usually between groups of professional businesses such as doctors and lawyers. The provisions contained in the bill are intended to provide a legal basis—and this is Senator Cherry's comment—for a current, longstanding practice within the postal industry. So much for radical change in this proposal. The proposed legitimisation of these practices, as provided for in the government's bill, will not result in the establishment of alternative end-to-end delivery services in competition with Australia Post. Let me put that on record. The safeguards contained in the bill will ensure that the document exchange services can continue to provide their current level of services but that they will not be able to vastly expand their membership with the intent of providing an alternative end-to-end delivery service. Australia Post has been fully consulted in the development of the safeguards and has given its full support to the proposed measures. We will not be supporting the Labor Party's proposal, which, as we all know, was probably drafted by the CEPU.
Question put:

motion.para: That items 11 to 14 stand as printed.

talk.start.para: —I move amendment R(1) on sheet 4201 in the name of the Australian Democrats:

quote.para: R(1) Schedule 1, page 6 (after line 34), after item 14, insert:
Insert:

para.inline: 30A Enforcement for infringement of reserved services

quote.para: (1) A person shall not engage in conduct that involves an infringement of Australia Post's exclusive right to undertake the reserved services.
(2) For the purposes of this section, person means any of the following:

speech.para: (a) a company;
(b) a partnership;
(c) a person in the capacity of trustee;
(d) any other person.

quote.para: (3) If the Federal Court is satisfied that a person has contravened subsection (1), the Court may order the person to pay to the Commonwealth such pecuniary penalty, in respect of each contravention, as the Court determines to be appropriate.
(4) In determining the pecuniary penalty, the Court must have regard to all relevant matters, including:

speech.para: (a) the nature and extent of the contravention; and
(b) the nature and extent of any loss or damage suffered as a result of the contravention; and
(c) the circumstances in which the contravention took place; and
(d) whether the person has previously been found by the Court in proceedings under this Act to have engaged in any similar conduct.

quote.para: (5) The pecuniary penalty payable under subsection (3) by a body corporate is not to exceed $250,000 for each contravention.
(6) The pecuniary penalty payable under subsection (3) by a person other than a body corporate is not to exceed $50,000 for each contravention.
(7) The Minister or the ACCC may institute a proceeding in the Federal Court for the recovery on behalf of the Commonwealth of a pecuniary penalty referred to in subsection (2).
(8) A proceeding under subsection (7) may be commenced within 6 years after the contravention.
(9) For the avoidance of doubt, the remedy in this section is in addition to that provided in section 31 of this Act.

speech.para: This amendment is to ensure that there is better enforcement for the infringement of the reserve service of provisions, which have just more properly been defined in the legislation. It is based very loosely on section 570 of the Telecommunications Act in that it establishes clear penalties for infringement of reserve services. Our view was that this provision was essential, having looked at the evidence coming out of the inquiry into these provisions, where in particular the Postal Office Agents Association made it clear that they felt there was a need in the legislation to include specific penalties to act as a proper deterrent to abuses. I do notice that Senator Kemp said in his comments that there are some safeguards in this legislation to protect the reserve services of Australia Post. I think it is a fundamental flaw that the provisions currently rely on civil action by Australia Post to protect its reserve services rather than a civil penalty provision, as is provided in other competition policy areas, in particular in the Telecommunications Act. This provision, as I said, is based on section 570 of the Telecommunications Act and it puts Australia Post on the same basis as Telstra in terms of ensuring that its reserve services are properly protected and enforced.

talk.start.para: —Democrat amendment (1) implements a penalty regime for persons found to be infringing Australia Post's exclusive right to undertake its reserve service. This, we believe, is in many ways the Democrats' mea culpa amendment. The Democrats' opposition to Labor's previous amendments, which we just all noted in that division, has allowed the legislative passage of the government's first attempts to begin chipping away at Australia Post's reserve services. This has allowed the thin edge of the wedge to be inserted. It has begun, and the government and the Democrats are there working as allies in conjunction. So this amendment, we believe, is to ease Senator Cherry's guilty conscience about his previous retrograde actions. However, having said that, Labor do support this amendment but we find it regrettable that the Democrats could not support our previous amendment, which would have ensured that the original, stronger Australia Post reserve service remained in place. We put out our hand for assistance and it was spurned, and now the thin edge of the wedge has been inserted. But we have not reciprocated. We are pleased to announce that we are able to support this Democrat amendment even though it is, as I said at the outset, a mea maxima culpa amendment.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —What an extraordinary intervention from Senator Bishop. I am sure Senator Cherry will survive that vicious personal attack. Senator Cherry knows, as I do, that despite the fact that we on this side of the chamber regard Senator Bishop as one of the more intelligent senators on the other side, we do note that when the CEPU gives him a call and asks him to run some lines he is as fast as the rest of his colleagues to get on his feet and do what the paymaster says. Despite your undoubted intelligence and the contributions that you can make, when it is vetoed by the CEPU I am afraid you are like the rest of your colleagues: you just dance to that tune.

speech.para: Senator Cherry will be upset to hear that we will not be supporting his amendment. The amendment, we believe, is unnecessary. Section 31 of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 already provides that Australia Post may apply to the Federal Court for relief where a person has engaged in conduct that infringes the reserve service. This relief may constitute an injunction and, at the option of Australia Post, either damages or an account of profits. The government believe that this mechanism and the relief that it provides is appropriate, and we note that Australia Post actively monitors potential breaches of its reserve service. The current provisions have been in place for over a decade and have worked effectively. The government note that Australia Post has sought relief for breaches of its reserve service on several occasions in the past in the Federal Court. Consequently the Democrat amendment would have little or no practical utility. In practice Australia Post is in the best position to monitor breaches of its reserve service and is also the appropriate body to pursue breaches in the Federal Court. The government also believe that the current relief provisions provided in the act, which include damages and an account of profits, are the most appropriate for breaches of the reserve service.

talk.start.para: —I just wanted to note for the record that the deregulation of reserve services occurred in 1994 under a Labor government, under communications minister Michael Lee. What we voted on today is only a tiny clarification of the extent of that exclusion. It seems that Senator Bishop's many qualities do not include a particularly good memory.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move opposition amendments (7), (8) and (9) on sheet 4149, revised 2:

quote.para: (7) Schedule 1, page 5 (after line 16), after item 10, insert:
Add:
(3) Without limiting the operation of subsection (1), the prescribed performance standards may relate to methods of determining the level of mail service for a particular area.
(8) Schedule 1, page 5 (after line 16), after item 10, insert:
After “Australian Post must”, insert, “, unless the Minister considers it unnecessary in the circumstances,”.
R(9) Schedule 1, page 5 (after line 16), after item 10, insert:
Insert:

speech.para: (1) The Minister may request the Auditor-General to monitor and report to the Minister on specified matters relating to Australia Post's supply of postal services.
(2) The Minister may publish the report.
(3) The Minister may exclude from the report referred to in subsection (3) any information that Australia Post claims is commercial-in-confidence information if the Minister is satisfied that:
(a) the claim is justified; or
(b) it is not in the public interest to publish the information.

These amendments, we believe, enhance the existing role of the Auditor-General to monitor Australia Post, which Labor has retained through the success of the opposition's first batch of amendments, moved at the beginning of this debate in the committee stage. In the bill, the ACA's postal monitoring role is similar to the Auditor-General's existing role, but the bill did contain some enhancements, it is fair to say, of that role. These enhancements relate to the new provisions in proposed sections 50C and 50E of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989, which have now been deleted in committee stage under opposition amendment (11), discussed previously.

Opposition amendment (7), which is before us now, relates to proposed new section 50C of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989. The new section 50C contained a clause which would have extended the standards regulation making powers of the ACA through the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989. As the EM of the bill explains, this new clause would enable standards to be prescribed relating to the processes used by Australia Post for polling communities to determine whether delivery services should be provided to a property. This would address the concern that Australia Post's current method of polling communities to determine whether to institute delivery services to a property has made it difficult for communities to convince Australia Post to institute these services.

A range of communities across our country that do not have delivery services to a property have been making a series of complaints to Australia Post, the government, the department and, indeed, all the political parties who take an interest in this matter. They have complained that the assessment process undertaken by Australia Post to determine whether there should be delivery services to a property is deficient and unsatisfactory and that it leads to incorrect or wrong responses, upon which Australia Post determines planning for new services. This is an objective of the original bill that Labor support in principle; we just have a different means of achieving that outcome, as outlined in opposition amendment (7). Labor support in principle the new wording of 50C, which allows for prescribed performance standards regarding the methods of determining the level of mail delivery service for a particular area, but we do not support the application of this new provision to the ACA rather than the Auditor-General.

The Auditor-General's postal monitoring role has been kept in place by our successful amendment (5), which ensures that division 1A of part 3 of the relevant act remains in place. Our amendment (7) simply applies the new delivery arrangements standards role to the Auditor-General using identical language to the original bill proposed for the Australian Communications Authority. Amendment (7) will enhance the Auditor-General's existing role and will achieve the same outcome, we believe, regarding regional delivery arrangements that the government sought to achieve through the ACA. The difference with Labor's approach is that this improved outcome will be achieved through a different agency—the agency that Labor believe is better suited to monitoring Australia Post, which, as we have now said repeatedly, we believe is the Auditor-General, not the ACA. In summary, therefore, Labor's alternative amendment (7) will simply apply the new delivery arrangements monitoring role to the Auditor-General's existing role.

The next in this series of amendments regarding the enhancement of the Auditor-General's postal monitoring role is opposition amendment (8). This again applies a minor enhancement of the postal monitoring role to the Auditor-General rather than the ACA. The bill's proposed section 50D mostly replicates section 28E of the existing act. Labor successfully defended the existing postal monitoring arrangements, including section 28E, in our amendment (4). Section 50D did, however, have a small enhancement on section 28E, which was that Australia Post was not required to prepare a service improvement plan if the minister considered it unnecessary in the circumstances. This minor change to section 28E recognised that Australia Post may address the reasons for a failure to meet a new standard before its failure to meet the standard is noted in its relevant report.

Furthermore, in such cases, the requirement for Australia Post to prepare a service improvement plan would clearly be unnecessary. Labor support in principle the merits of the new wording of original section 50D, as reflected in our proposed amendment to section 28E(1). Our previous amendments in committee have kept section 28E of the act intact and have also defeated proposed section 50D of the bill. Opposition amendment (8) applies a slight enhancement of Australia Post's service improvement plan arrangements to the original section 28E. Therefore, the objectives of the government's aim in the new wording of proposed section 50C remain in place in our proposed amendment to 28E.

The government also planned through proposed new section 58E to allow the minister to direct the ACA to monitor and report to the minister on specified matters relating to Australia Post's supply of postal services, which the minister has referred to in some of the committee debate. Labor do not have major objections to this new provision in principle; we just have a problem with the fact that it applies to the ACA and not to the Auditor-General. Therefore, having defeated proposed new section 50E of the act, Labor's amendment (9) re-enacts a version of that enhanced role outlined in section 50E. Again, it applies to the Auditor-General and not to the ACA.

Under opposition amendment (9), which creates a new section 28F of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989, the government's proposed additional reporting role will apply to the Auditor-General, not the ACA. Labor's amendment (9) is worded slightly differently to the bill's original proposed section 50E to take into account the fact that the Auditor-General should not be directed by ministers. Therefore, the wording states that the minister may request reports rather than require reports, as would have been the case with the ACA.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will be supporting these amendments for the reasons I outlined earlier. I would like to comment very briefly on the role of the Auditor-General, in particular in response to a comment from Senator Kemp earlier in the debate when he indicated that the Auditor-General just audits. Performance auditing has been a fundamental part of the Auditor-General's role in Australia for a very long time and is increasingly a significant part of the Auditor-General's role. Performance auditing goes way beyond just auditing; it actually covers the fundamental issues of effectiveness, value for money and delivery against performance standards. From that point of view, the Democrats believe it is appropriate for the Auditor-General to continue to perform the role, which it has done effectively in Australia Post now for a good decade, and it is also appropriate that that role be enhanced in the way that has been suggested to cover the issues the government raised in its original bill in terms of mail delivery in particular regional areas. The Democrats will be supporting these amendments and we commend them to the Senate.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —I am sorry that Senator Cherry was not persuaded by my earlier arguments. As I said, his form in this debate is becoming more variable again. The government will not be supporting the opposition's amendments. The government's bill, just to recap, proposes a range of expanded independent oversight functions in relation to Australia Post which it proposes should be exercised by the ACA. The effect of the opposition amendments would be that some of the proposed roles of the ACA would be performed by the Auditor-General; others would not be performed at all.

speech.para: The Auditor-General's office is an agency whose principal function is that of auditing. The proposed expanded oversight powers in relation to Australia Post, which would deliver greater transparency and accountability to government and consumers, go much further than auditing. It should be noted that the Auditor-General outsources its current function of monitoring Australia Post's performance against prescribed standards to an accounting firm. The oversight function is clearly more appropriately carried out by the ACA, which performs a similar role in relation to the telecommunications industry. If the CEPU works out that there is outsourcing involved there, I suppose we will have another amendment from the Labor Party.

The ACA is an independent regulator with the requisite expertise to monitor and report on Australia Post's performance in the supply of postal services. It has seven years experience in developing processes and mechanisms to monitor and report on performance in the telecommunications market. The experience that it has gained over this time can be, I am advised, appropriately applied to establishing performance monitoring arrangements in relation to Australia Post. We will not be supporting the amendments moved by the Labor Party.
Question agreed to.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill. The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 23 March 2004. I move government amendment (1) on sheet RC238:

quote.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 22, page 12 (line 24) to page 13 (line 22), omit section 56A, substitute:

para.inline: Recovery of costs incurred by the ACA and the ACCC
Minister may estimate costs for financial year

quote.para: (1) The Minister may, during a financial year:

speech.para: (a) estimate the ACA's and the ACCC's costs for that financial year; and
(b) notify Australia Post of the Minister's estimate.

para.inline: Minister may determine actual costs for previous financial year

quote.para: (2) The Minister may, in a financial year, determine the ACA's and the ACCC's actual costs for the previous financial year.

para.inline: Minister may direct Australia Post to pay adjusted estimated costs to ACA and ACCC

quote.para: (3) The Minister may, in a financial year, direct Australia Post:

speech.para: (a) to pay to the ACA, on behalf of the Commonwealth, the Minister's estimate of the ACA's costs for that financial year, adjusted in accordance with subsection (4) or (5); and
(b) to pay to the ACCC, on behalf of the Commonwealth, the Minister's estimate of the ACCC's costs for that financial year, adjusted in accordance with subsection (7) or (8).
(a) in the previous financial year, the Minister directed Australia Post to pay an amount to the ACA; and
(b) the Minister determines that the ACA's actual costs for that previous financial year exceed the costs the Minister estimated for the ACA that year;
the amount the Minister may direct Australia Post to pay to the ACA under subsection (3) is increased by that excess.
(a) in the previous financial year, the Minister directed Australia Post to pay an amount to the ACA; and
(b) the Minister determines that the ACA's actual costs for that previous financial year fall short of the costs the Minister estimated for the ACA that year;
the amount the Minister may direct Australia Post to pay to the ACA under subsection (3) is reduced by that shortfall.

quote.para: (6) The ACA must, as soon as practicable, bank any amount it receives under subsection (3) in an official account within the meaning of the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997.

speech.para: (a) in the previous financial year, the Minister directed Australia Post to pay an amount to the ACCC; and
(b) the Minister determines that the ACCC's actual costs for that previous financial year exceed the costs the Minister estimated for the ACCC that year;
the amount the Minister may direct Australia Post to pay to the ACCC under subsection (3) is increased by that excess.
(a) in the previous financial year, the Minister directed Australia Post to pay an amount to the ACCC; and
(b) the Minister determines that the ACCC's actual costs for that previous financial year fall short of the costs the Minister estimated for the ACA that year;
the amount the Minister may direct Australia Post to pay to the ACCC under subsection (3) is reduced by that shortfall.
