In fact, neither the ALP nor the ACTU has any interest in small business, the area of the economy in which most Australians work. We know that Labor does not have anything to offer small business. Former leader Kim Beazley said so, publicly. He said that Labor had never pretended to be the party of small business. At least he was honest about it. Under its present leader no-one knows what Labor stands for in the most vital area of the economy—small business.

speech.para: Last night in the House of Representatives the Treasurer presented his ninth budget. It is a budget that responsibly adds to the support mechanisms available to Australians, emphasising family and the home. It responsibly outlays funds whose receipt by Australians will enable them to enhance the choices they make on how they run their lives. It is a budget that looks after our security, spends money on defence in a newly dangerous world, adds to the education and welfare infrastructure, and still provides a surplus. It does all of this in a global environment in which there are dangers, economic and otherwise, that make budgeting particularly difficult.

The Treasurer has been able to deliver this sensible ninth progression in our national economic fortunes because, among other things, the Howard-Costello government's business policies—particularly its small business policies—over the past eight years have been consistent, and consistently strong. With strong business policies comes strong economic growth, and with strong economic growth comes the realistic opportunity for a government like the Howard-Costello government to deliver—as it did last night—more help for families; income tax cuts; massive boosts in retirement savings; very significant increases in spending in the vital areas of health, education, national security, the bush, and road and rail infrastructure; and, significantly for small business, real reforms to the GST administrative processes which will reduce paperwork.

I want to say more about the budget at a later time. In this speech the matter of public interest to which I draw the attention of honourable senators is Labor's industrial relations policy. The advantages that have been enjoyed by small business under the Howard-Costello government for the last nine years—and the additional advantages announced in last night's budget—would be utterly negated by Latham's industrial relations policy. A Labor government that imposed on small business the outcomes that are predicated on its industrial relations policy would be a complete disaster for this country and for small business.

Labor has no answer when it is confronted on the fundamental issue of growing employment opportunities. It would prefer—presumably at the behest of its paymasters in the big unions—to send small business broke by imposing employment conditions on it that are not only unconscionable but also unfair and, frankly, quite stupid. It would make small business play the big business game—with all the attendant big business costs—in matters such as unfair dismissal actions. It would say that it was doing so because it wanted to be fair to the employees of small businesses. But it would be wrong. I believe that it knows it would be wrong; therefore, it knows that what it is trying to sell to the Australian voter is a lie.

In fact, what Australia needs to hear from the Labor Party is that it has some vision for our country's industrial relations future that does not rely for its inspiration on ideas that are fixed in the increasingly distant past. Labor should listen less to its old union mates and more to the voices of other industrial organisations—for example, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The ACCI is not a class enemy, after all. In the 21st century the notion of class enemies is not only derisory—and it was always derisory in Australia—but also, plainly, old hat.

Much has been made lately of the fact that union membership is creeping up again. Labor doubtless sees this as a vindication of its policy of reinventing the past. But it might just as easily be the result—and I know that honourable senators opposite will not admit this—of the positive employment policies that the Howard government has pursued with vigour and courage over the past eight years. I am here today to take some credit on behalf of the government for the increase in union membership that some of the good senators across the chamber boast about. The reason for that is that we have created more jobs—more people in employment—and, of course, some of those people have chosen to join a union.

Record job creation has put many more people into secure employment, in larger companies as well as in small businesses. But, even so, union membership in the private sector—and this is instrumental—is at a historic low. Our workplace legislation means that people can belong to a union if they wish to—we on this side of the chamber are not about compulsion as a matter of policy—and the fact is that the evidence shows that a large majority of employees see no point in joining a union. That is a problem for the union movement. It is one it could solve quite easily, if it could find the will to do so, by moving to become relevant in today's workplace. It is not necessarily a problem for the Labor Party—if you forget about the $40 million the unions have pumped into the ALP over the term of the Howard government. The Labor Party's problem is that it, too, must find a way to become industrially relevant.

In a paper produced after the Labor Party's national conference in January, the ACCI said some very interesting things. In particular—and I recommend that those opposite take particularly close note of this—it said:

quote.para: For business observers at the conference and for industry more generally, it is the policies of the Australian government and those of the Opposition that matter most. Whereas trade unions campaign for a change of Australian government to suit their political colours, commerce and industry want an Australian government of whatever political colour to embrace policies that are in the national interest and best for economic development and jobs.

speech.para: The ACCI is an independent, fair dinkum, unbiased organisation. The ACCI noted:

quote.para: An interesting measure of the Australian Labor Party's 2004 industrial relations platform is to compare it not just with federal Coalition government policy but with the industrial relations policy of the most recent federal Labor government, that of Paul Keating. Prime Minister Keating expressed the ALP policy vision in these terms in 1993:
“It is a model which places primary emphasis on bargaining at the workplace level within a framework of minimum standards provided by arbitral tribunals.
It is a model under which compulsorily arbitrated awards and arbitrated wage increases would be there only as a safety net.
The safety net would not be intended to prescribe the actual conditions of work of most employees, but only to catch those unable to make workplace agreements with employers.”

speech.para: Now isn't that interesting? What a difference of substance—I am talking about the structure envisaged, not the refinement of it or the difficult issue of delivering such an outcome—really exists between what Paul Keating described in 1993, 11 years ago, and what the Howard government has delivered in office since 1996. It may be that Paul Keating knew that he could never deliver what the country needed in terms of industrial relations. Judging from the performance of those opposite since they went into opposition in 1996, I would have to say that he probably knew that he would never deliver. He has form for non-delivery, after all. We all remember the l-a-w tax cut that turned out to be an l-i-e. Nonetheless, a policy of workplace bargaining within a framework of minimum standards and a regime not intended to prescribe the actual working conditions of most employees were Labor Party policy in 1993. That simply cannot be denied.

Mr Keating was able to enunciate that policy without the sky falling in or the earth reversing its orbit around the sun. I would like to think that the light on the hill may even have flickered more brightly—just for a moment, before it returned to the glum glow that is its usual state—at this evidence of forward thinking and the faint hope that somewhere in the leadership of the post-socialism Labor Party there existed some grasp of the fact that forward momentum is essential for real progress, particularly industrial progress. That was, as the ACCI says in its post Labor Party conference paper, a visionary position. The ACCI gives credit where credit is due. It headlines its paper `ALP should match Keating vision on industrial relations reform'. There is a great opportunity for the Labor Party here—a genuine opportunity to go back to the past. It only needs to go back 11 years to rediscover commonsense and positive policy.

The 2004 Labor platform, the one dictated from ACTU House—like the earlier 2000 platform of a similar provenance—talks of `comprehensive, contemporary and relevant awards', of `giving a greater role to the independent Industrial Commission' and of `increases in wages and conditions through the award system and industry based arrangements' and promises only to lead to new or additional regulation. In short, it is not a roadmap to the future—a future in which more and more Australians have more and better choices and greater freedoms. It is a signpost to the past—a past where everyone made do with the one-size-fits-all arrangements that suited union bureaucrats, workshop enforcers and enterprise-numbing restrictive practices. This is what the Labor Party proposes to foist on Australia if it is elected to government. This is the Latham plan for modernising our country—to clamp it back in a union mandated straitjacket. It is simply madness.

The national unemployment rate is 5.6 per cent seasonally adjusted—the lowest in 22 years. Long-term unemployment is the lowest in 13 years. As the ACCI points out in its excellent paper—I recommend it is closely studied by those opposite—unemployment has been reduced through a combination of economic growth and labour market reform, including changes to industrial relations policies and practices. It says that a freeze or, worse still, a regression on labour market and industrial relations reform would put these outcomes at risk.

For small business, undoing the reforms of the past eight years—incomplete though they may be because the Labor Party will not recognise reality and prefers politicking to policy making—would be an absolute disaster. The Labor Party would make small business liable to the ruinous costs of big business's unfair dismissal rules and make every enterprise the object of union rights of entry. Perhaps nothing better describes the Labor Party's complete inability to understand small business than those two facts.

The Howard government has the runs on the board. The people of Australia are the beneficiaries of greater industrial flexibility and greater employment opportunity. In the face of this benefit—in the face of consistently lower inflation, higher productivity, higher real wages, lower interest rates, fewer disputes and strikes, record employment and lower unemployment—Labor wants to re-regulate employment. Its platform expresses support for the goals of economic development, competitiveness and productivity. It commits to `full employment' and `an unemployment rate sustainably below five per cent'. Yet it proposes to regulate wages and employment conditions by a collective system and to abolish all statutory individual agreements, including Australian workplace agreements, that form the legal basis of the wage and employment conditions of 455,000 Australians and 7,600 businesses. That is not only stupid—it is also unfair. It shows that Labor in 2004, under Mark Latham, is interested not in freedom of choice or expanding opportunity but only in giving back to big union power its former right to call the tune. It shows that Labor in 2004 is no option for Australia or its enterprising employees and employers, particularly small businesses, which are the engine of growth in our economy. They are genuinely concerned about the employees that they have taken on, unlike those opposite here in the Senate and in the other place.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Health Services

talk.start.para: —I begin by advising the Senate that today is International Nurses Day. I ask and encourage all honourable senators to acknowledge the important contribution to Australia's health system that nurses make. They certainly belong to a dedicated and undervalued profession and need to be supported and appreciated by us all. Today I rise to speak on a matter of public interest and that is the provision of rural and remote health services in Australia. I draw the Senate's attention to two important recent government publications. The first is a document entitled Connecting government, released by the Management Advisory Committee, and the second is the report of the National Audit Office performance audit of the Department of Health and Ageing's management of the Multipurpose Services Program and the Regional Health Services Program.

speech.para: Over six million Australians—that is, 34 per cent of the total population—lived in rural or remote areas in 2001. That is a significant proportion of the population. Typically, the health of those people is worse than that of people living in metropolitan areas. For example, life expectancy is higher in metropolitan areas and death rates increase with remoteness. You may not know this, but they are 10 per cent higher in regional and remote areas compared with major cities and 50 per cent higher in very remote areas. Rates of hospitalisation are also higher for remote Australians compared to those living in capital cities. As we have heard from all the Medicare committee inquiry consultations, the rate of general practitioner consultations is also lower. In general, health workers and pharmacists are underrepresented in rural and remote areas. Therefore, access to health services is likely to be much more limited for people living in rural and remote areas compared to people living in major cities. Additional contributors to poor health and higher mortality in rural and remote areas include lower socioeconomic status, higher risk of injury as a result of the types of work and conditions experienced, lower quality roads, Indigenous health needs, physical inactivity, overweight and obesity, smoking, hazardous or harmful alcohol consumption and poor diet. That is a long litany of contributors.

The purpose of my contribution to today's debate is to focus on the Multipurpose Services Program and the work that multipurpose service centres provide in rural and regional Australia. Health services in Australia are provided by a combination of public, private and not-for-profit organisations. State governments, partly funded by the Commonwealth through Australian health care agreements, are responsible for the provision of health services through the public hospital system. The Commonwealth Department of Health and Ageing is responsible for implementing the Australian government's rural health policies and priorities.

The Multipurpose Services Program, which was the subject of the recent audit, is a joint program between the Commonwealth and state governments. It aims to provide a flexible and integrated approach to the delivery of health and aged care services to small rural communities, so it is a very important program for rural and regional Australia. The services provided by multipurpose services vary, but they can include residential aged care, acute care, community and allied health, rehabilitation and health education. The Commonwealth funds the aged care portion of MPS and the state government funds the other identified health needs. The Commonwealth is the minority funder of the program, providing around $45 million a year. Commonwealth funding of an individual MPS is contingent on the commitment of the relevant state government to providing the recurrent funding and the capital funding where necessary. The total Commonwealth and state government funding to the 86 MPS operational last August amounted to almost $188 million a year, which is a significant proportion of the health budget.

The Regional Health Services Program, which was the second program in the National Audit Office performance audit, is a Commonwealth program that helps small communities expand their local primary health care services. Services provided by a regional health service may include allied health care, health promotion and prevention and general practitioner services. The Commonwealth funded 152 regional health services as at 31 August 2003.

The objective of the audit of the National Audit Office was to assess the effectiveness of the Department of Health and Ageing's management of both the MPS Program and the Regional Health Services Program. Generally, the ANAO found that there was effective management and that the performance indicators developed for the two programs were consistent with the programs' objectives. But the ANAO raised some very specific concerns that I want to put before you today. First of all, the ANAO found that Health staff do not have confidence in the integrity of the data held by the central rural health database, and this is a very significant finding. In fact, it was found that Health staff have independently developed effective systems to monitor services that shadow the centrally developed rural health database and that that has led, of course, to inconsistencies between the data held in the database and that held by the state offices. Those data inconsistencies combined with the limited access to the database have meant that the database does not meet the needs of state office staff, so the department of health's central office staff do not have confidence in the integrity of the data held by the database.

Significantly again, the ANAO found that the performance information is not being used effectively, that the data on individual services is not collated or analysed systematically and that Health is not using service performance data to identify good practice or potential improvements to the programs. In addition, Health does not have baseline information on health service provision or health outcomes and consequently is not able to measure the progress of the two programs against their respective objectives. That hardly seems to be good enough.

A third finding, and another concern, of ANAO was that Health has developed a risk management plan for the Regional Health Services Program but not for the MPS Program. There is no risk management plan for the MPS Program as a whole. That, again, is of concern to us all. The ANAO found that there is a systematic approach to identifying MPS sites and that once these are identified they are assessed against the selection criteria, which is consistent with the program's objectives and ensures that MPS are placed in communities most significantly in need of what is a very flexible model. The ANAO found that the principle of that flexible, pooled funding that forms the basis of an MPS funding model is also consistent with the objectives of the MPS Program. That is an important point that I want to come back to.

The ANAO found that one-third of the MPS are operating with extended funding agreements, with almost half of the extended agreements originally expiring in or before 2001. Therefore, MPS are operating with agreements that may be implementing service delivery plans that are not current or relevant to current community needs. The ANAO expressed concern that targets included in the MPS funding agreements—which of course are bed numbers and budget figures—are input measures that guide funding levels but are certainly not adequate measures of outputs or outcomes. In addition, the bed numbers are only indicative. Applying the principle of flexible funding, funding provided to MPS may be used to provide any appropriate aged care services. Therefore, as bed numbers are not an accurate description of the actual services provided, they are not a useful target. It was found that the financial controls and management of the MPS were sound but that the department of health's knowledge of state government contributions to the MPS Program was limited. However, the ANAO noted that the Commonwealth and state governments have recently agreed to change the reporting arrangements. This, again, is an important point that I will come back to.

Significant for rural Australia is the fact that the ANAO found that Health has identified a significant financial issue in the level of underspent RHSP funds. Funding was increased by 9.6 per cent in the last budget but $6.6 million was not spent by the Regional Health Services Program during this two-year period, which really is not good enough for small rural and regional communities where health services are stretched to the limit. The ANAO found that Health has not identified or systematically analysed the reasons why rural health services are not using available Commonwealth funds.

I will now move to the second report, Connecting government: whole of government responses to Australia's priority challenges. I am not sure whether you have heard of this report, but it is a very significant document that was released only a few weeks ago by the Management Advisory Committee. It is an important document as much for what it does not say as it is for the approach to service delivery and decision making it promotes. The document promotes whole-of-government thinking and action and it provides case studies of how this is happening at the Commonwealth level. Dr Shergold, Chair of MAC, launched the report. He said:

quote.para: Australians rightly demand the delivery of government programs and services in a seamless way. That is what they see and, to a significant extent, that is what Centrelink delivers.

speech.para: Centrelink was one of the case studies. He continued:

quote.para: They should also expect that, behind the scenes, all the resources of government will be coordinated in the search for innovative solutions to complex policy.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: Good policy will always be undermined by poor implementation. Bad policy will always result if it is not informed by the operational experience of those who deliver programs and services at the front desk, in the call centre or by contract management. The problem of structural demarcations exist at least as much within departments as between them. That is why, too often, program managers in Canberra believe that their regional staff are insufficiently aware of the environment of political contest in which they operate and why, conversely, regional staff are inclined to the view that the national office is unable to comprehend the challenges they face implementing policy on the ground.

speech.para: He then went on to say:

quote.para: A whole-of-government approach also requires knowledge of how a policy is likely to be perceived by those who are to be affected by it. It is entirely appropriate that a public servant facilitate discussion with those bodies who seek to represent, advocate or lobby for interest groups.
In a real sense citizens are stakeholders in the making of public policy.

speech.para: There are some important lessons in both these publications. The ANAO report suggests that guidelines for the MPS Program are effective but that guidelines for the Regional Health Services Program are inadequate. The Regional Health Services Program state office guidelines were developed in the first year of the program but were found not to assist Health staff with program management, to be out of date and to contain inaccuracies. So, in fact, those kinds of guidelines were not being used by staff. On the one hand we have the Multipurpose Services Program, an innovative and responsive model for the hard decisions about service delivery in the regions, which needs whole-of-government thinking—and that was not demonstrated in the ANAO report. On the other hand we have the Connecting government document promoting whole-of-government practice, which needs to be translated into genuine action on the ground in the regions in a much more proactive way than is currently the norm.

The MPS Program and the Regional Health Services Program are a small but significant response to the challenge of service delivery to regional Australia. The programs rely heavily on good relations between the Commonwealth and state governments and on a genuine partnership approach with communities, which depends on those communities being supported in making some difficult choices about their health service mix. As I said before, the pooled funding model used in the MPS Program is a very good model for dealing with those challenges, but we do need to ensure that we have connected government, a whole-of-government approach and departments working together to deliver those outcomes for regional Australia.

talker.name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
Senator BARTLETT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —Tomorrow night, as is traditional for the Leader of the Australian Democrats, I will be giving a full response on behalf of the Australian Democrats to the government's budget proposals that were tabled in this chamber and in the other place last night. But I want to outline now our responses to some of the core components of the budget and, indeed, go to a core lesson and a core message that can be taken from this government's behaviour in just the last 24 hours with respect to the budget and the situation in Iraq. In just the last 24 hours I believe this government has demonstrated once and for all that any notion that it is strong and responsible on economic management or that it is strong on national security has clearly gone out the window. Any suggestion that it is a careful manager of money or that it will spend it appropriately in the public interest has gone out the window. This highlights again the importance of the Senate in trying to ensure that public money is spent responsibly and effectively, not just stashed away to the side for a tidal wave of pre-election spending every three years.

speech.para: The budget is dishonest because it is not economically responsible, and the Senate must more clearly acknowledge and take credit for its role in ensuring that the economic fundamentals of this country are much stronger than they would otherwise be. The Senate must continue to try to ensure that the public expenditure passed by this parliament is as economically responsible as possible. That is why we must scrutinise this budget's spending measures, particularly the huge amounts of largesse being dished out on an election eve. This government has long tried to argue that it is the only one that is economically responsible. This budget, nonetheless, as many economic commentators have said, runs the real risk of increasing interest rates by putting $4.2 billion extra cash into the economy before 30 June, with another $8.2 billion to come in a tidal wave next year. Household debt, as the budget papers show, is now 150 per cent of household income. In 1996 household debt was only 75 per cent of household income. It has doubled in the life of this government. In the early eighties it was only 40 per cent.

The last thing that Australia needs is the risk of another interest rate increase. We probably will not get it before the election, particularly if this government rushes to the polls, but that will not stop Australia facing the consequences after the polls. That will particularly be the case if the Labor Party's response is to pass all this spending and then to promise some extra spending to fill in the gaps for those people who missed out. The massive increase in household debt and the fact that the government has so much money is of course in part due to the housing boom that has fuelled housing unaffordability. Measures such as tax breaks for high-income earners—which they already get through negative gearing, through the capital gains tax discounts and through building allowances—have fuelled the investor driven housing bubble. It has failed our health and education system but is actually saving nothing for the looming intergenerational crisis. It is putting the economy at risk by putting in such a tidal wave of money leading up to an election.

The government are also dishonest in saying that they are strongest on making Australia safer. There is the intelligence money, for example. The Democrats welcome that. We have repeatedly said that we welcome more resources for the intelligence community, but clearly there is a cloud over the effectiveness of the operations of our intelligence agencies. I know we are very careful about acknowledging our sources these days, so I acknowledge The Chaser magazine as the source of this appropriate headline: `Mr Howard doubles ASIO budget, demands twice as much faulty intelligence.' There is no point putting extra money into intelligence agencies when there is clearly a need to ensure they work more effectively first.

Similarly, there is continuing evidence about significant wastage and gross overspending in defence purchases. Not enough is being done to address that. It is one thing to say you are putting extra money in, but unless those areas are working properly you are putting good money after bad. That is more economic mismanagement and it does nothing to make Australia safer. We are continuing to waste defence money on patrolling Australia's oceans to keep out refugees and asylum seekers. We are continuing to waste money on mandatory detention and the Pacific solution. All of that does nothing to make Australia safer; it misdirects the energies of the defence community.

The budget is dishonest because it has not properly addressed the long-term structural needs of families. It might address the short-term electoral needs of the government—we shall see. What we need is responsible expenditure of money that actually addresses problems in a sustainable, ongoing way, not in a short-term, lump sum handout way. The short-term, cynical funding in the budget encourages people to go forth and multiply; it does not consider the ongoing needs of the average Australian family and must be condemned. Again, it is dishonest. The vote-buying lump sum family benefit payments are not going to bring the 700,000 children and their families out of poverty. Any extra money is obviously welcome, but to spend it in such a one-off irrational way is clearly not the best use of public money.

There are no real incentives to address unemployment and underemployment, which is around 13 per cent, other than this extraordinary exhortation from the Treasurer to work more overtime to reach the higher tax brackets and benefit from the government's absurd tax cuts. At a time when we are supposedly trying to fix the balance between work and family, the Treasurer is saying that low-income earners can benefit from this by just working more overtime. The fact is that over one million Australians are living in poverty, despite living in a household where one or more adults are in employment. The tax cuts will do absolutely zero for those people.

The overwhelming conclusion of most submissions to the recent Senate committee inquiry into poverty and financial hardship is that this government should offer a hand up and not a handout to those living in poverty—something you would think the conservatives would support, but this budget has failed to do that. The government is dishonest in talking about these tax cuts as being aimed at middle-income Australians. Mr Howard talks repeatedly about middle-income Australians. He says, as he did again this morning, that hardworking middle-income Australians need an incentive. I do not begrudge extra tax assistance for middle-income Australians; I just wish they were actually getting some. Frankly, I do not begrudge extra income tax assistance for people earning higher amounts, but the suggestion that high-income earners need tax cuts as an incentive to work harder but low-income earners do not get tax cuts as an incentive for them to work harder is grossly offensive and again dishonest.

The statistics clearly show that these tax cuts will help less than a quarter of taxpayers—around 2 million people who have taxable incomes over $52,000. That is not in the `middle' in anybody's language. I am not saying that people on an income of $52,000 do not deserve some extra assistance, that they could not benefit from it, that it is a huge income or that they are rich. Let us not see more dishonesty from the government by misrepresenting what the Democrats are saying here. The fact remains that the vast majority of Australians are below the so-called middle level of $52,000 a year that the government has highlighted. The suggestion that people earning $60,000 or $70,000 a year—as the Prime Minister is saying—are middle-income earners is simply not correct. That does not mean that they cannot do with some assistance but, from the Democrats' point of view, it certainly means that people who earn less than that will miss out on assistance.

Unlike the Greens, the Democrats do not say that noone should get an income tax cut. We recognise, as was quite clear in the Senate inquiry into poverty, that tax relief for low- and middle-income earners in particular is a very important way of helping people out of poverty. The Democrats have repeatedly said that in the lead-up to this budget. People who are on middle- and low-incomes actually pay the highest effective marginal tax rates—higher than people in the top tax brackets. So of course they should get some income tax relief; the fact is that they are not getting any. The Greens do not want to give them any; they do not want anybody to have income tax cuts. The Democrats say that it is fine if we are going to have income tax cuts but that they should be shared more fairly. If we are going to spend that amount of money—and it is an enormous amount of money; bigger than we should have, in our view—then any form of income tax relief should be spread fairly. The government's continued insistence that this is a fair budget is again dishonest.

One of the most frustrating aspects is that the opportunity to improve this budget—which is the Senate's responsibility, as it has always been—is apparently going to be lost because the Labor Party appear to have chosen to vacate the field and allow all this through. That is despite statements by Mr Latham saying that this budget is deeply flawed and unfair. Well, that bit is honest, but their response is still to let it through. The problem is that there is no rewind button on legislation: once it is passed, it is through. If it is deeply flawed and unfair and it is passed, then it is locked in as deeply flawed and unfair.

It is important to emphasise that that would not be the first time. For all the talk about Mr Latham taking a new approach compared with the small target approach of Labor in the past, I think it is worth revisiting Labor's record under Mr Beazley, for example. I draw the attention of the Senate to an article written by Margo Kingston in the Sydney Morning Herald nearly five years ago now, on 27 November 1999, in which she pointed to the occasion when the Labor Party, the party of labour, agreed to capital gains tax changes which `overwhelmingly benefited the wealthy and dramatically disadvantaged small business compared with big shareholders'. Mr Latham was actually quoted in that article as saying, `Under this government, the more you earn the bigger proportion of your earnings you receive in a tax cut. It's a multibillion dollar free kick for the rich.'

Using Mr Latham's language, it was a multibillion dollar free kick for the rich that Labor passed five years ago because Mr Beazley wanted to vacate the field and focus solely on the area on which he wanted to fight the election. It appears we will have that same thing happen again. People are elected to the Senate to actually do the job here. You cannot do the job in the Senate for two years out of three and then say in the third year, `There's an election coming up so we'll just let all the bad stuff through and let people make another choice at the election.' There is a reason why the Senate has fixed terms that are not cut to the election cycle—that is, so that we can continue to assess legislation as it is put before us in terms of the best needs of the Australian people, not the best needs of the Prime Minister's election timetable. It is very important that we get the opportunity to address some of these flaws.

As this government has to acknowledge, when it is not engaged in political rhetoric, the Democrats have shown that we will be constructive and responsible in the Senate. Over the last month leading up to the budget we put forward a range of proposals. We repeatedly said that funding should go to services first, and I believe the majority of the community want that. This budget has failed in that regard. It has not put the extra money into housing, health, education or the environment, where it is clearly needed. We also said that, if there were income tax cuts—and we all knew that was going to happen in a pre-election environment—they should be shared fairly. Clearly that has not happened. These are government proposals. They are not government imprimaturs from on high that must be forced through without change. All parties in the Senate have at times voted to amend or reject income tax and other tax changes; there is nothing special about these tax changes that says they must be pushed through just because there is an election around the corner. Indeed I would argue that the fact that there is an election around the corner makes it all the more important to properly scrutinise them rather than allow them to be rushed through.

The family payment changes, as welcome as they are, maintain the dishonesty of saying that they meet the needs of working mothers, because they do not put in place a legislative entitlement to paid maternity leave. Australia's working women should have an automatic entitlement to take leave to have a child, in the same way that they have an entitlement to sick leave, holiday leave and other leave. We have still fallen short of that and, whilst it does provide welcome extra assistance, to suggest that this package meets even the basic needs of something as important as maternity leave is dishonest.

So there is a lot that needs to be scrutinised. Let me remind the Senate and the public that there are only nine Senate sitting days before the end of June. If we have an election in August, that is all the time we have in which to pass all this legislation that the government wants to rush through, let alone everything else it has backed up. That is bad governance and bad policy, and it is something the Democrats do not believe the Senate should be a part of. It would be dishonest of us to say that we will run for the election and be a part of the Senate if we do not then do our job properly. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Honesty and integrity have taken flight from the Western Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party. One of the first things the new Labor government in Western Australia did in 2001 was to let the Attorney-General, Jim McGinty, continue his obsession with changing the state's electoral laws to disenfranchise voters in regional Western Australia. Mr McGinty took his fight to the High Court of Australia, at taxpayers' expense. This was his second attack to get to the High Court, having twice previously failed in the state Supreme Court. Once again his argument was thrown out.

speech.para: McGinty, the first law officer in Western Australia, proclaimed his assault to be in the name of electoral fairness—one vote, one value. Hypocrisy and deception run all the way to the top in the Labor Party government in Western Australia. Mr McGinty is one of the principal beneficiaries of an internal vote-rigging scandal currently unfolding in Western Australia. The aggravating fact is that this rorting and corruption have been alive and well inside WA Labor for more than five years. Indeed, many Western Australian Labor members and senators in both the federal and state parliaments owe their positions to the flawed and corrupt internal voting processes inside their state Labor Party.

Labor in WA is a party dominated by factional war lords, usually union heavyweights, who will stop at nothing in their relentless pursuit of power and privilege. These war lords meet deep in the bowels of Curtin House to divvy up the spoils of preselections and party leadership positions according to who has the most votes on the state executive, all based on the number of members belonging to a specific union or branch. Put simply: the more members in a union or branch, the more votes on preselections. So much for one equal vote to each member of the Labor Party within Labor Party voting processes. It is a textbook definition of hypocrisy and is light-years away from any fair notion of one vote, one value. Where is Mr McGinty's obsessive zealotry for electoral reform when it comes to reform of his own house and his own party? He should resign. He is obviously a person unsuitable to be in charge of the administration of justice in Western Australia.

This factional warfare had its historical genesis in October 1999, when a deal was done between the ALP factional heavyweights around Perth to create two new alliances. Unions associated with the far Left, and controlled by de facto premier, Jim McGinty, formed an alliance with current state Labor president, Michelle Roberts, and the federal member for Perth and shadow immigration spokesman, Stephen Smith, in a grouping that is now known as the New Right. The New Right does not have a large union base, but relies overwhelmingly on branch memberships—the bigger the branches, the bigger its influence, and I will say more about this later. This Left and New Right grouping has become the dominant faction within the Labor Party in Western Australia, guaranteeing its hack members all the spoils of power in terms of party positions and winnable seat preselections.

The losing factions from this alliance were those associated with former Labor Premier Brian Burke, of the Right, and the Centre Left, headed up by CFMEU chief, Kevin Reynolds. Things came to a head when Brian Burke wanted a senior public servant, Darryl Wookey, to be preselected for Ballajura at the last state election. The problem was that the federal member for Perth, Stephen Smith, had promised the seat to his close friend and former campaign manager, the Mayor of Bayswater, John D'Orazio. So came the great split of the Right, enabling the ambitious Michelle Roberts to take the party presidency and the despotic Mr McGinty to take control of Labor Party affairs in Western Australia.

Premier Gallop, who was the state Labor opposition leader at the time, harboured paranoia over the power and influence of Burke and Reynolds in the party and supported D'Orazio. It became a show of strength and Gallop, supported by McGinty and Roberts, won. D'Orazio was duly elected at the 2001 state election and is now chair of the powerful Public Accounts Committee within state parliament. What Gallop unwittingly did was create a monster. The short-term gain in defeating Burke and Reynolds conversely empowered McGinty and Roberts who, with Smith, now control every aspect of the Labor Party in Western Australia. As a further consequence, state cabinet is now dominated by factional hacks dictated to by McGinty, Roberts and Smith.

Prior to the last state election much commentary came from all quarters on just how unfair and undemocratic the Labor Party in Western Australia was in handling its own preselection issues. An article on former Keating minister Gary Johns was published in the Bulletin on 18 April 2000, which said:

quote.para: Johns has spent three years researching a PhD on preselection procedures. His research reinforced the view that Western Australia's Labor Party had the most “crooked” preselection of any ALP branch. “Local branch members have no say in preselection, there is no sense of democracy in WA—it [has] the most overwhelmingly union-dominated preselection rules. Branch members are irrelevant—it is whatever the main union characters at the time think.

speech.para: Vote rigging has been endemic inside Labor in Western Australia for more than four years now and has only lately been understood by the media. The first hint of the magnitude of this scandal was during a parliamentary debate on ministerial standards and codes of conduct on 22 November 2000. The then coalition state government minister for planning, Graham Kierath, revealed that the current minister for consumer affairs, John Kobelke, had been caught red-handed in vote rigging. He was dobbed in by a Labor Party member who had had enough of the lies, deception and large-scale vote rigging that was the modus operandi of powerbrokers inside WA Labor. In the state parliament, Minister Kierath said:

quote.para: I have a photocopy of a calling card from John Kobelke, the member for Nollamara. On the back is a hand-written note which states—

speech.para: John payed for your membership to his branch the Balga-Nollamara Branch only to find you were a member of the Girrawheen Branch. Please sign the enclosed form, and you will then be transferred to our branch.
Thank you
Ann Roberts—
the electorate officer of Kobelke. The quote goes on:

quote.para: The Leader of the Opposition—

speech.para: as Mr Gallop then was—

quote.para: intended to clean up the pre-selection process of the Labor Party, and now we find the member for Nollamara paying for other people's branch memberships, in contravention of his own new constitution, which was designed to clean up the Labor Party.

speech.para: Kobelke responded the next day, saying that this was an isolated case and he was only helping out an old pensioner. This explanation was not true. This was in November 2000, nearly five months after 30 June when the membership was renewed. The person who signed the note on his behalf was not only the membership officer for the branch but also his electorate officer.

Minister Kobelke had been caught red-handed and, unbelievably, his disingenuous explanation was swallowed whole by both his party leadership and the media. The pensioner involved actually came into the then office of the Premier and cabinet and handed over the calling card from Minister Kobelke to one of the Premier's advisers. He told the adviser that he had not been a member of the Labor Party for years and was disgusted to find out that his name was being used for blatantly corrupt political purposes.

The second event signifying the extent of WA Labor's vote-rigging rorts was revealed by senior investigative journalist Tony Wright in an article in the Bulletin on 16 January 2001. In this episode, two members of staff in the office of the Labor member for Swan were found to have rorted the parliamentary travel allowance scheme to the tune of $9,000. Why would they do this? What was the motive? Who was the beneficiary? The answers are simple—factional powerbrokers and the chance to boost the membership of the branches in the electorate of Swan. The two staff members in the member for Swan's office were foot soldiers of the emerging New Right faction, jointly headed up by the now shadow minister for immigration, Mr Smith, and ALP President, Michelle Roberts.
Simple mathematics tells you that $9,000 goes a long way to paying the party membership fees of a lot of people. In his Bulletin article, Tony Wright said:

quote.para: Rumours circulating widely within the ALP have it that some of these memberships are in the names of “ghosts”—people who are dead, who don't exist or who have been signed up without their knowledge.

However, senior insiders who have spoken to the Bulletin are more inclined to believe that if there are indeed ghosts on the books, they are likely to be people who joined the ALP years ago, who had allowed their memberships to lapse and, without their knowledge, have had their annual membership fees paid. In this way, there would be no unusual jump in membership numbers—they would appear to remain stable, even though some former members might have moved away, or thought they had quit the party, or had even died. A sum of $9,000 is enough to pay for several hundred memberships. One long-time ALP figure put it simply: “The more branch members you have on the books, the more influence you have in the party.”

speech.para: The upshot of this is that the two staffers had established in the member for Swan's office a de facto headquarters of the shadow minister for immigration's New Right faction, with membership numbers in the branches totalling around 1,200. All of a sudden the New Right had some factional muscle, courtesy of the blatant vote-rigging subterfuge within the office of the member for Swan.

An internal review by the Labor Party—doesn't that sound familiar!—cleared the member for Swan. Surprise, surprise. However, the review was not so kind to the loyal factional staffers. Both were given their marching orders. The third person employed in the office, a member of the Left who actually blew the whistle on the other two by copying their personal computer files, remained—protected, no doubt, by factional allegiance. Four years later, Western Australians now know that these examples were not isolated cases of vote rigging—they have been entrenched and endemic throughout Labor Party processes in Western Australia for years and years.

It has recently been revealed—and admitted by the member for the state seat of Ballajura, John D'Orazio—that he and his brother have been involved in vote-rigging scams for a number of years. Respected investigative journalist Paul Murray reported on the extent of vote rigging by the D'Orazio clan in the West Australianon Saturday, 3 April. He said:

quote.para: I'd been alerted to a secret investigation being held by the secretary of the Labor Party, Bill Johnston, into allegations of branch stacking in the Cowan electorate council, particularly in the branches affecting the State seat of Ballajura, held by John D'Orazio.
I'd been told to pay attention to people who had been signed up who lived outside Ballajura. Ringing through the lists, I found Greta Fox who lives in Belmont, well out of the electorate.
Greta told me she had been signed up by a bloke called Tom who came to her home to talk to her son, Scott, about hiring a stretch limousine. Tom had asked Scott to become a member of the ALP.
“He said it wouldn't cost us anything ... He said he was trying to sign up 600 members for his brother.
It didn't take too much work for me to find out that “Tom” was Tom D'Orazio, the brother of John, the MP.
... John D'Orazio's huge branch memberships—far and away the most impressive in the metropolitan area—get him about 15 votes in the Cowan electorate council's share of 200 ALP State executive votes.

speech.para: On 7 April 2004, ABC News reported that the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union had been exposed for reporting a membership of 10,000 one day and the very next day saying it was 14,000. The extent and seriousness of this corruption has not had the spotlight from anybody on my side of politics. The whistleblower is a member of the old Right faction, headed by former Premier, Brian Burke. On 7 April in the Herald Sun, Tim Clarke reported:

quote.para: Senator Bishop claimed two unions—the Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union ... and the AMWU—inflated their membership figures.

He said the votes altered the balance of power in a series of contests, including preselection for a Legislative Assembly seat, and also helped install Police Minister Michelle Roberts as party President.

speech.para: Documents evidencing these grubby matters have been forwarded to the Police Commissioner and the WA corruption commission for investigation.
On radio 6PR on 7 April this year, the Police Commissioner said that fraud allegations indicated a criminal offence. He said:

quote.para: On our examination, there did appear to be a likelihood of a criminal offence.

speech.para: One of the principal beneficiaries of the rort, Michelle Roberts, is both the Minister for Police and Emergency Services and the President of the ALP in Western Australia. In WA we are now confronted with the possibility of the Police Commissioner investigating, or worse, his minister. If the WA Premier has any regard for notions of good government, he should at least stand her aside until the inquiry is completed and the Police Commissioner delivers his verdict on what charges should be laid, if any, and against whom.

A recent secret internal review of Labor branch stacking conducted by State Secretary Bill Johnston produced an adverse result for police minister Michelle Roberts and shadow minister for immigration, Stephen Smith. The New Right faction has been found to be responsible for blatant branch stacking and vote rorting in Labor Party branches over a number of years. It has been revealed that more than 30 per cent of ALP members in the New Right faction cannot be verified. Paul Murray, in the West Australian on 22 April this year, said:

quote.para: Forged signatures and fake membership forms have been uncovered in a preliminary investigation into branch stacking in the WA Labor Party.
ALP State Secretary Bill Johnston says `hundreds and hundreds' of Labor's 5700 WA members may be caught up in the rorting, mainly in the so-called phantom memberships.

speech.para: The following day the state Labor member for Perth, John Hyde, a member of the New Right-Left alliance, alleged in a confidential report that high school and foreign students had been signed up as party members without their knowledge. The West Australian on 23 April this year said:

quote.para: In the report leaked to The West Australian, Mr Hyde detailed cases in which he said Year 12 students at Mount Lawley SHS were told that their memberships would be paid for a couple of years if they signed up.

speech.para: The West Australian on 1 May said:

quote.para: The State Executive is currently split 119 to the New Right-Left and 95 to the Centre-Old Right. But a splinter group within the New Right, said to be led by the ambitious Vince Catania, son of former MLA Nick, has set its sights on John Hyde's seat of Perth.
The name that keeps popping up is John Hyde, one MP said.

Mr Hyde won the nomination for his safe seat of Perth by swapping from the Centre to the Left. To the Centre-Right, that's a hanging offence. If Mr Catania jumps to the Centre-Old Right, taking up to seven votes with him, Mr Hyde could be in trouble.

speech.para: The question arising from all of this turmoil is: what is Premier Gallop doing to bring order to his party and to the state government? The answer is: very little, given that he is hostage to the controlling faction of the day. The West Australian on 5 May this year reported on the success of Premier Gallop's re-attempt to establish some modicum of control over this scandal when it said:

quote.para: By all accounts you could have cut the atmosphere—

speech.para: inside the Labor Party room—

quote.para: with a knife, that is if you could find one that wasn't buried deep between someone's shoulders.

speech.para: We wait with bated breath to see what Premier Gallop does about Attorney-General Jim McGinty; police minister Michelle Roberts; Minister for Consumer Affairs and Employment Protection, John Kobelke; and Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, the member for Ballajura, John D'Orazio, who have all been clearly caught out as vote riggers under the same rules. Premier Gallop said on 13 April 2004:

quote.para: If a Labor Party MP is found to be engaged in serious malpractice and that was proven by proper Labor Party processes, well they're not the sort of people we would want standing for the Labor Party.

speech.para: However, it is at the federal level where all eyes will be on the Leader of the Opposition as he ponders what to do about his shadow minister, who has been decisively caught out as the leader of a group of serial branch stackers in clear contravention of Labor Party rules 15(a) to (q) inclusive. The Leader of the Opposition said on 10 April:

quote.para: Anyone who has broken the law will have no future in the Australian Labor Party ... I will ensure anyone who's broken the law is placed right outside the party.

speech.para: Labor in government in WA is obsessed with power and who wields it. So much for the delivery of services and good government!

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on an issue which I have spoken about previously—the government's continued attempt to make South Australia this country's nuclear waste dump. I want to speak to the Senate today about the next step in the sorry saga of the Howard government's disregard for the wishes of the people of South Australia. We know that South Australia has been chosen by this government as the site for a nuclear waste facility, despite other suitable sites being identified through the EIS process. We know that this government has ignored enormous opposition from the South Australian community in proceeding with its plans to dump nuclear waste in South Australia. We also know that this government has ridden roughshod over the wishes of the elected state government, compulsorily acquiring the land for the site without negotiation—a matter which is still the subject of legal challenge before the South Australian Supreme Court.

speech.para: Now the next sorry step in this saga has also been revealed. We know from freedom of information documents obtained by the South Australian government that this government has embarked on a taxpayer funded campaign to change the minds of the people of South Australia so that we will no longer oppose this dump. We know that the federal government has engaged expensive consultants to try and change the community's mind through various means. Frankly, if you read the FOI documents what is disclosed is a range of what can only be described as Big Brother tactics by this government as it seeks to spread misinformation and its own propaganda about the nuclear dump. We also know from the freedom of information documents that the government kept the door open on the possibility of a medium-level dump and the possibility of a high-level dump, sourcing nuclear waste from overseas, being placed in South Australia.

Let me give some background regarding this issue. The federal government has for a number of years been seeking to construct both a repository for low- and medium-level waste and also a high-level waste dump—known as `the store'—which would be capable of receiving waste from around the world. It is also well known in South Australia that the American company Pangea Resources had a proposal to site an international nuclear waste repository in South Australia. This would involve South Australia receiving nuclear waste from around the world—hardly the sort of export earner one would have thought that we would want for our state.

It is a matter of history that there was enormous opposition to both of these proposals in the South Australian community and in the face of this furious opposition, prior to the last election, Senator Minchin did an about-face on the issue of a high-level dump. Whilst he had previously left the door open for both the repository—that is, the low- and medium-level dump—and the store, or the high-level waste dump, being sited in South Australia, he ruled this out prior to the last election. He also ruled out, despite having previously left the door open, the Pangea proposal for a high-level dump receiving nuclear waste from other countries being sited in South Australia. He ruled this out in February 1999—it was a relief to many people in South Australia that he did so—but, thanks to the FOI documents which have been released, we now know that, despite this categorical denial by the minister, the federal government kept its options open. The federal government engaged consultants to conduct polling in December 1999, June 2000 and February 2001, which included questions about not only the low-level dump, which was government policy, but also the Pangea proposal to receive high-level nuclear waste from other countries into South Australia—to import nuclear waste.

The question is: if the minister did categorically rule this out in February 1999, why was it necessary to use taxpayers' money to fund a campaign to conduct polling—including on the issue of the Pangea proposal? It probably, to any fair-minded observer, calls into question the reality of the denial by the minister that this proposal would proceed; it also calls into question other commitments that this government has given regarding the siting of a high-level dump in South Australia. Why, if Pangea's proposal for a high-level dump, including foreign waste, was dead and buried in February 1999, was this government still exploring this option through its consultants, its research and its polling of the South Australian community?

This raises serious questions regarding the assurances the South Australian community has received from the federal government on two issues: first, that it will not allow the importation of foreign nuclear waste and, second, that it does not intend to site the store for high-level waste in South Australia. An equally disturbing impression one gets when reading these freedom of information documents is the extent to which this government is willing to engage in its own version of Big Brother, its own version of propaganda, to try and change the minds of the South Australian community. These documents reveal quite a conscious campaign to turn South Australian voters around. I assume most senators know that it did not work; the vast majority of South Australians and the state government are still implacably opposed to the dump.

But the FOI documents really are an example of the way in which this government is seeking to use taxpayers' money to get out its own message. We all remember the A New Tax System ads—a shameful example of taxpayers' money being used to further a political agenda—and in these documents we see the government seeking to use public funds to try and achieve a political result to its liking. One example is the discussion in the documents regarding the `I'm with Ivy' campaign. For those of you who are not from South Australia, Ivy is a South Australian pensioner who led the community based campaign against the nuclear dump and sponsored a petition, which many South Australians signed, opposing the low-level and medium-level dump in South Australia. Interestingly, what we have here is an email to a public servant from someone above her which says:

quote.para: The minister wants a short biography of our main opponents in the Ivy campaign by about 11 a.m. our time (pre-rally).

speech.para: What we have here is a minister wanting to check up on those in the community who actually opposed him. The only comment I would make, apart from the obvious one that this is not the way we should be spending taxpayers' money, is that he would have had a very long list if he wanted a biography of everyone associated with that campaign. Another disturbing document in the FOI file we received was from the government's consultant to a public servant. In this document the consultant describes his conversation with a journalist, whom I shall not name, and he describes people opposed to the nuclear waste facility as `antinuclear anarchists'. If that is the definition, it seems that we have a pretty anarchic state given that over 90 per cent of South Australians oppose this dump.
The freedom of information documents also detail, in the brief to the minister, quite a detailed public relations scare campaign seeking to change community opinion on the issue. This brief says:

quote.para: This would involve a concerted program of letters to the editor of the Advertiser and responding and participating on talk radio programs. A significant public forum such as business lunch, for example—

speech.para: and a certain business organisation is named—

quote.para: ... may provide a relatively secure forum for a well-known proponent of the repository to address opinion leaders in South Australia. Similarly, the minister could host smaller lunches with opinion leaders.

speech.para: The brief goes on to make some comments about the media in South Australia, and the Adelaide Advertiser in particular. It is pretty instructive, when you read it, to look at how this government goes about trying to change media opinion. The following is also in the brief from the consultant to government:

quote.para: The Advertiser tends to set the media agenda and has been a vocal opponent of the facility. While we understand attempts are being made to make contact with the editor, we should continue to push for a meeting with the editor or managing director and seek assistance to achieve a fair and balanced coverage. If this fails, the issue should be taken to the higher levels of News Limited.

speech.para: It is a pretty interesting expose of the way the government tries to approach media management and tries to ensure that people run its lines and run its spin. I am pleased to say the Advertiser has, in relation to this issue, continued to listen to its readership, continued to be in touch with the South Australian community and continued to provide very fair reporting on the issue of the nuclear dump. What is disturbing for South Australian taxpayers is the sort of campaign and agenda that is clearly disclosed in these documents. They are Big Brother tactics, tactics to try to disseminate misinformation about an issue to which the South Australian community is quite rightly opposed.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —I take the opportunity in summing up this debate on matters of public interest to note with very great concern the revelations made by Senator Johnston on the corruption, vote rigging and rorting in the Western Australian branch of the Labor Party. That is the sort of thing that I think would concern all Australians: the vote rigging, the buying of votes, the signing up of non-existent people—the sort of thing that really is un-Australian. I would certainly hope that the more honest elements of the Labor Party would do something about the Western Australian branch.

speech.para: It seems that if you need a morbid, depressing and despondent view of anything, you can always rely on my Queensland colleague Senator Bartlett to put it, and he was in his best form of despondency in his views on life today when speaking on the budget. I was surprised that Senator Bartlett did not mention the very positive things in the budget for middle income earners and lower income earners. The significant advances in family tax benefit A will see $600 going to those people immediately and another $600 going to them very shortly. I am surprised that Senator Bartlett did not mention the very great initiatives in aged care, new funding—$6 billion more—for education, and the significant increase in spending on defence matters.

Senator Bartlett shares that very left-wing view of his party and the Greens particularly, having cynicism about intelligence. They never seem to appreciate the need for intelligence. I was just concerned that Senator Bartlett had to have this depressing view of the budget when there is such good news in it for most Australians. I think most Australians appreciate that this government's good financial management has allowed the government to be able to pay some of that back to the taxpayers, and that is what it is all about. It is important to emphasise that the money that is available in this year's budget did not just float down from heaven; it is there by a lot of hard work by Mr Howard, Mr Costello, Mr Anderson and the rest of the government in properly and very carefully managing our economy over the last several years. It is as a result of that hard work and very sound and careful financial management that we have been able to provide a budget that I think will provide benefits to most Australians.

Most importantly, I was surprised that Senator Bartlett, as a fellow Queenslander, did not highlight the additional $656 million that will be available to the Queensland government next year as result of the federal budget and as result of the sound economic management of the Howard government. Now, $656 million extra to the Queensland budget is a very significant injection to my home state of Queensland. With that additional money, I am quite confident that Mr Beattie will be well able to afford, in his budget, reductions in stamp duty on family homes and reductions in that insidious tax that state governments involve themselves in—that is, payroll tax. With all of this additional windfall money that the Queensland government will get from the Howard government, I am sure Mr Beattie will be able to do a number of good things. I would simply urge Mr Beattie to look more widely than Brisbane when he spends this money.

As someone who lives in the country up in North Queensland, I am always concerned that the Queensland state government's view of Queensland seems to finish at the boundaries of the south-east Queensland local authorities. While it is good to see south-east Queensland getting money, the Queensland government has spent an inordinate amount on things like the Lang Park redevelopment, the Goodwill Bridge across the Brisbane River—a walking bridge, I might say—whilst, up in the sticks, we get little of Mr Beattie's largess. But he now has 656 million new dollars to help Queenslanders provide more schools and more hospitals, and I am certainly looking forward to seeing how Mr Beattie will spend that windfall from the Howard government.

The other two things I was surprised Senator Bartlett did not mention include the structural adjustment money that has been made available for the representative areas program of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. That will provide structural adjustment for fishermen who will lose income, for communities and other businesses that might be in some way impacted upon by that very sound approach and sound environmental management of the Great Barrier Reef. I am also surprised Senator Bartlett did not mention the money that has been provided—some $444 million—for the sugar industry, which is such an important part of Queensland. The sugar industry supports many communities up and down the coast of Queensland, and the injection of $444 million will help the industry through a very difficult time that has occurred through no fault of the sugar industry. It is quite clear that farmers and businesses up in that area did need some support, and that has been provided for in this budget.

The budget is obviously one which has many benefits for all Australians. We are able to provide these benefits because of the very good financial management by the Howard government over the last several years, and I think most Australians would agree with us in thinking that this is a budget for all Australians. It is certainly a budget that will keep Australia moving forward and keep the economy heading in the direction it should.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Coonan, the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Revenue. Is the minister aware that the Howard-Costello government continues to extract more in bracket creep than it returns in tax cuts? Can the Minister for Revenue explain to the Senate why the tax cuts offered by the Howard government will return $1.9 billion in 2004-05 to taxpayers, but around $2.5 billion will be clawed back in bracket creep this year?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Conroy for giving me the opportunity to explain some of the budget measures that deal with the issue of bracket creep. The government's 2004 budget tax cuts come on top of those already delivered through the new tax system in 2000, which were $11 billion per year, and a further $2.4 billion in tax cuts in 2003. When taken together, these three tax cuts will have more than returned bracket creep since 1996. In 2004-05, someone on average weekly earnings—around $40,000 under the new tax scales announced in the 2004 budget—will be about $550 better off than if the tax scales had been indexed to the CPI. The finding that taxpayers are better off is true for those earning half average weekly earnings or twice average weekly earnings. As a result of the government's tax cuts, over 80 per cent of taxpayers will face a top marginal tax rate of 30 per cent or less. Reductions in tax rates combined with real growth in wages over the past nine years will have increased the real disposable income of the average individual earner in 2004-05 by 13 per cent.

answer.para: The notion that bracket creep is not returned is completely unsustainable. This government is continuing to deliver ongoing tax reform and structural tax reform. As a matter of fact, the combined effect of three stages of tax reform has delivered significant tax cuts for all Australians. There has been some suggestion that this is only for the rich. That is also nonsense. Taxpayers earning $20,000 paid $2,770 in tax prior to the new tax system. They now have a reduction of around 23 per cent in tax. For those on $50,000 the reduction is around 21 per cent. By July 2005, if the Labor Party do not muck around and they pass this tax package, those on $90,000 will get a reduction of around 18 per cent. These are ongoing structural tax reforms that benefit all Australians and the economy.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister for Revenue confirm that, whilst the government will return almost $5 billion in tax cuts in 2007-08, almost $7 billion will be clawed back into Commonwealth revenue through bracket creep in the same year? Given that the government is only returning to taxpayers part of the proceeds to Commonwealth revenue through bracket creep, isn't Prime Minister Howard just giving with one hand but taking even more back with the other?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Conroy for the supplementary question. Senator Conroy appears not to understand that bracket creep occurs when inflation pushes taxable income into a higher tax bracket, and of course this government has a very good record on inflation. The government has a record of low inflation, averaging 2.4 per cent since March 1996. Interestingly, by contrast, under the previous Labor government inflation rose to 11 per cent, an average of 5.4 per cent over 13 years. If anyone listening to this broadcast is worried about bracket creep, they had better be very afraid of any return to a Labor government.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Will the minister inform the Senate how the Howard government's responsible management of the Australian economy is providing Australians with greater family assistance, more affordable health and aged care and personal income tax cuts? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable senator for his question. Last night's budget continues the Howard government's outstanding record of strong and responsible economic management. The budget for the year ahead will deliver a surplus of $2.4 billion, the seventh surplus for this government. This budget is designed to keep the economy strong. The economy is strong because the government took the hard but necessary decisions to get the budget back into surplus. We remember that the Labor Party opposed almost all of those decisions. Because of our commitment to responsible economic management we can again deliver a dividend to Australian workers and their families. This is a government that promises and deliver tax cuts—$12 billion of tax cuts in the tax reform package, $10 billion of tax cuts in last year's budget and now a further $14.7 billion of new tax cuts announced in last night's budget.

answer.para: These latest tax cuts will mean that more than 80 per cent of taxpayers will have a top rate of 30 per cent or less. In addition to the tax cuts, we are also delivering further assistance to Australian families, with increases in the family tax benefit, a new maternity payment of $3,000 and more child-care places. In total, we will be investing more than $19 billion in Australian families. We have delivered more money for aged care, more money for education, more money for health, more money for the environment and more money for national security. We are giving greater assistance to Australians who are saving for their retirement. These commitments are fully funded within a budget that is in surplus. We do not spend money that we do not have. We will maintain, again, a responsible surplus—this time one of some $2.4 billion.

By contrast, the Labor Party say they will support our new tax measures, but they claim that on top of that they will give even greater tax cuts. We know that they have made promises already of over $8 billion. We have a surplus of $2.4 billion and the Labor Party offer an extra $8 billion in cuts. What does this mean? This means the same old recipe of going back into deficits—that which Australians experienced before with the consequence of higher home loan interest rates, job losses and ultimately higher taxes. Their policy platform, passed just four months ago, supports budget deficits. We know their record: nine budget deficits in just 13 years. Labor broke their promise on the l-a-w tax cuts, they wrecked the Australian economy, they put a million Australian workers out of work and they crippled Australian families with interest rates on home loans of 17 per cent. If they are given the chance, they will do it again with irresponsible, unfunded promises to anyone who will listen. The lesson is: you cannot trust Labor to manage the economy. The contrast is stark. We have seen the benefits of the good economic management of the last years. There is a chance for more of that if the Howard government is given the opportunity. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! I would like to draw the attention of senators to the presence in the President's gallery of two very special guests: Mrs Robyn Kelly and Dr Paul Kelly of Benalla in Victoria. Mrs Kelly this morning became the 20 millionth visitor to Parliament House since 1988. In just 16 years a number of people equivalent to the population of Australia has visited this building to see democracy in action. As President I know that all senators will agree that that is a wonderful thing to do. I warmly welcome Dr and Mrs Kelly to the Senate.
